dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (as we fade in) . with purity in our hearts, with right thinking in our minds, we arm ourselves with an intolerance of all evil! Thus, it is on this glorious Sabbath morning, in this momentous year, 1887, that we naturally turn our thoughts to that way of life as exemplified by Victoria, Our Beloved Queen. For this week begins Her Majesty's Golden Jubilee. Her strength and goodness, her Christian principles, have walked in the light of God ever since her ascension to the throne. From her heart has come an ever-increasing flow of virtue and moral blessing with which she has endowed us, her loving subjects. As the man speaks we BOOM BACK AND AROUND SLOWLY to disco ourselves in All Souls Southwick Church, London. The man speaking is the Bishop, talking from the pulpit, backed u by the well-appointed magnificence of the Anglican altar. PAN AROUND the congregation in the pews. For the most, th are the well-dressed and well-bred families of the period listening attentively.

And though we know not the time nor the season, we know that Evil in God's own time shall be wiped out by God. At this point the Bishop is startled by the interruption a high-pitched, scornful evil laugh coming from the back the church. He looks up.

dialogues.text: (bowing to a lady and gentlemen) Harrison... good morning! (turns to Beatrix and Jekyll) Well, we've just time for a turn in the park -

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX

dialogues.text: I must get to the hospital, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Hospital? On a Sunday? Oh, you mean that outrageous individual that -?

dialogues.text: Harry says Providence dropped the poor man right into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: But this is most unusual, my boy. You know, we always take our stroll before --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but it is, sir. Most unusual. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: By this time they have reached Sir Charles [...] smart op carriage. A footman stands holding the door open for them groom, in similar livery, is on the box.

dialogues.text: (turning to him) See you at the Marley's tonight, now. Don't be late.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: And let you have free rein with all those men? He kisses her on the lips, much to Sir Charles' consterna She laughs and gets into carriage. Sir Charles, nervous a the kiss, looking about to see who has noticed it, follow Beatrix into carriage.

dialogues.text: (picking up her hand - kissing it) There's really nothing about you that I like at all. As he holds her hand, he makes a surreptious little bite it.

dialogues.text: He has been watching; he starts nervously as he sees Jeky do this.

dialogues.text: The carriage drives o.s. Jekyll starts backing away, in t opposite direction, waving to Beatrix. He backs into a fa old dowager. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Higgins is the woman with the man who caused the disturbance in the church. She is sobbing silently in con to Beatrix and WE PULL BACK to see her standing outside a door in the corridor of the hospital. AS WE HOLD the door opens and a young interne steps out with a rather surreptitious look back into the room. All we can see in room is the end of a bed with a man's feet strapped to it

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Higgins, as door opens) Now, Doctor, my lad - as man to man - we know what's fun in life and what isn't! Eh, Doctor? The man laughs wildly. The interne closes the door quietl and WE PAN HIM as he hurries down the hall to the end, an enters a door.

dialogues.text: On it is marked: "House Physician - Dr. Heath."

dialogues.speaker: INTERNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. But Dr. Jekyll insists going ahead with treatment.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But that mustn't be! The man's under observation!

dialogues.speaker: INTERNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. That's what I told him, but -- You better come, sir. The young interne comes out with Dr. Heath, a matured physician of about fifty. Dr. Heath wears a worried frown his face. WE TRUCK WITH THEM a little way back toward the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEATH
dialogues.text: (agitated - as they come out) He has no right to do such a thing!

dialogues.speaker: INTERNE
dialogues.text: I suggested it would be better that he consult you first, sir - but he still --

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEATH
dialogues.text: I know. Thank you, Fenwick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WE PAN them on down the hall to the door where Mrs. Higgi is waiting.

dialogues.text: Dr. Heath enters the room. Mrs. Higgins sobbing, puts her hand on the interne's arm as he is about to follow. Insid the man Higgins is laughing evilly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGGINS
dialogues.text: Isn't there anything they can -?

dialogues.speaker: INTERNE
dialogues.text: Everything possible is being done, Mrs. Higgins. Dr. Jekyll knows more about your husband's case than any other mental specialist in London.

dialogues.speaker: HIGGINS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (from inside) Why! Here's another doctor! But don't ask him! He's too old! The interne closes the door. The man's high laugh comes f inside. Almost immediately the door is opened by Dr. Heat who comes out with Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HEATH
dialogues.text: It's a matter of ethics, Jekyll. I can't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGGINS
dialogues.text: Dr. Jekyll, can't I go in and --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (gently, patting her shoulder ) Not yet, Mrs. Higgins. Bear up now. That's the way you said you'd help - remember. Continues to Heath as WE PAN THEM DOWN the corridor, Jeky obviously trying to control himself

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But, good heavens, man - this is the chance of a lifetime for me. The more I see of the case the more I realize it. The stop a little way down the hall, opposite an open unoccupied room.  19 20 21 22 12.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's quite possible that this case might fall within the bounds of your research. You know how we've all admired your other work in the past. And personally, I'd like to bow to your opinion here, but in my position as head of the staff, I cannot countenance -- He stops and realizes they are being watched o.s. as he l down the hall.

dialogues.text: She stands looking at them pathetically, wringing her han

dialogues.text: (indicating open door) Better come in here. They go into vacant room and close door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGGINS 22
dialogues.text: She looks at the room her husband is in, then starts timorously along the hall to the door behind which are He and Jekyll. WE HOLD A SECOND here. She would like to go i She starts to knock. Jekyll's and Heath's voices are only murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (suddenly rising clear) But I'm not witch doctor!

dialogues.speaker: HEATH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (rising, too - very clear) Who's called you a witch doctor? You told me yourself you've had no definite success. I can't allow you to experiment with - There are sudden quick footsteps toward door, and it is f open by Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (following him) Why, the man's a human being -! Jekyll wheels on him at the door, his eyes blazing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: You mean he was a human being! And he'd have another chance at it, if you'd keep your hide-bound ethics out of this! There aren't any rules for discovering medical Utopia! Or perhaps you haven't the courage to face what might be the greatest -! He stops, glaring impotently at Heath, who steps back a little, so vehement is Jekyll's look and attitude. Then, with an inarticulate growl of disgust, Jekyll wheels away quickly, AS WE TRUCK AND PAN with him to the end of the corridor and around the corner. The tension of his anger relaxes into a bitter smile as he walks along. He passes some swinging glass opaque doors marked: "CHILDREN'S WARD and is about to go on when he thinks of something and tur back, entering the ward.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Hello, Poole...

WE PAN HIM back he puts the rabbit into the experimental cage and then PA HIM as he picks up a heavy glove and puts it on his hand. stops by a cage in which is a large wharf rat, and reache in for it with his gloved hand.

dialogues.text: He backs into a corner as Jekyll's hand enters and then springs at Jekyll's fingers, biting the leather. But Jeky hand pins him down by the back of the neck.  20.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: She reacts to her father's frown and turns to smile casua at something said farthur down the table.

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB
dialogues.text: (under all this) We had a perfectly shocking meet at Ascot, didn't we? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Puggie Wilson has a wonderful new filly, I understand... A good chance for the Oaks this year... Of course she's rather pretty - but my dear, her father is in trade.... The poor boy's just down from Cambridge -- simply exhausted from work... Education demands sacrifice, doesn't it? Etc. Beatrix! expression suddenly lights up as we HEAR Jekyll' Voice o.s.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marley -!

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM 39
dialogues.text: Jekyll is just entering the dining room from the drawing room, followed by a footman who has evidently just admitt him. Jekyll heads straight for Mrs. Marley. The men rise.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL AND MRS. MARLEY 40
dialogues.text: She looks at him a little stiffly as she offers her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: My deepest apologies.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY
dialogues.text: (slightly sarcastic) I know - you doctors - we can never rely on you, can we?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (turning on charm, over her hand) Mrs. Marley, I'd rather be reminded of my short-comings by the smartest hostess in London than to be on the Jubilee Honors list.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY
dialogues.text: (with a double-take, completely mollified) Ch! Sit there, Dr. Jekyll... She indicates vacant seat o.s., and we PAN Jekyll as he w to it.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (to standing gentlemen) Gentlemen, please... Good evening, Bishop - John - Colonel Weymouth - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB
dialogues.text: Ah, Doctor... Harry... good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (looking at Beatrix - as butler pulls out chair muttering) Been behaving yourself?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX 41
dialogues.text: As she laughs, and looks around the table.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JEKYLL 42
dialogues.text: As he sits down between Beatrix and Lady Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (to Lady Cooper - yet feeling for Beatrix's hand) Lady Cooper - my short-comings are rewarded.

dialogues.speaker: LADY COOPER
dialogues.text: (a coy dame) Naughty man. There is correct laughter at this "risque" dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: A doctor's life, eh, Harry? The more patients, the colder the soup.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Wasn't a patient, exactly. I started something in the laboratory and just forgot to lock at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (a little patronizing) Ah, yes, Jekyll - Heath was telling me you're still carrying on with that research of yours.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (with a wry smile) I'm afraid Dr. Heath isn't quite - well, in sympathy, Dr. Courtney.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Well, that's understandable, isn't it? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Separating the facets of the brain... a little ambitious, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (stung) My research hopes to go deeper than the brain -- into something more intangible than the mind, even.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (looking at others with a laugh) Well, all that seems to be left is the soul. Colonel Weymouth and Marley laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: All right. Have it that way. Because that's just where I am aiming -- at the soul. A maid, putting his soup in front of him, looks extremely startled.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES AND OTHERS 43
dialogues.text: He locks amazed at Jekyll 0.s., puzzled and frowning.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The soul?

dialogues.speaker: AD LIB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good heavens... did he say "soul"? What does he mean...? Etc.

dialogues.speaker: LADY COOPER
dialogues.text: The soul! How thrilling!

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: (genially) Come, come - my dear doctor - now you're invading my territory.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (looking at him with a serious smile) Yes, my Lord - and I hope I may be of some assistance.  45 46 24.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 45
dialogues.text: He is a little startled by this radical statement and wis to assume that Harry is joking.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: My dear Harry - of course, you don't mean this?

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JEKYLL 46
dialogues.text: He looks quickly over at Sir Charles, picking up the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But I do, Sir Charles. Just consider that poor chap in church this morning. If you didn't see him, you all heard him, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. I thank you for your assistance there, Dr. Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (with finality) Hopelessly insane. Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY
dialogues.text: Why, the simply shocking things he said...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He wasn't insane. There was just one side of him in existence. And that side was speaking the truth.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEYMOUTH
dialogues.text: Good heavens! Which side?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: His evil side. The man has been spiritually distorted through shock... that explosion in the gas mains last month. Before that he was a fine, solid citizen - gentle and kind with his children - deeply in love with his wife. Since then, he's suffered a complete change - so that this afternoon I saw him entirely reverted to the animal - slythinking and vile, dangerous and rapacious, by turns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LADY COOPER
dialogues.text: (in the silence, edging a little from Jekyll) Mercy -!

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 47
dialogues.text: The other maid is just taking away his dessert, plate. Th maid looks wide-eyed at Jekyll o.s. Sir Charles is very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (shifting uneasily) Yes... ahumm...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (trying to pass it off casually) But Harry - what's that to do with the soul? We can clearly understand it as an injury to the nervous system and therefore --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (now lost in his subject, earnestly reasoning) No, no, John - I insist he has been shocked from normal good into complete evil. When I said before he was a "good" man, I didn't mean that he didn't have a bad thought or two from time to time -- and perhaps commit his portion of transgressions against the laws of civilized society. Because, after all - that is the problem of civilized Man's soul -the good and the evil in it are constantly fighting one another.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JEKYLL AND BISHOP 49
dialogues.text: The Bishop is the least affronted, very interested, but adamnantly patient.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: There is a Higher Source from which the good may always find aid in its fight, Dr. Jekyll....

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I realize that, sir - but...  26.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WEYMOUTH
dialogues.text: (haughtily - her hand possessively on Colonel's arm) Of course. The Colonel and I always feel that people can be good if they wish to be - and, well - otherwise, if they don't.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (with a snort) Exactly. Discipline! Everything else is poppycock! (then militantly changing subject with a joke) Haw! But men going dotty and all that do amusin' things at times. I remember our sergeant during the second Punjab campaign. We attacked and --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WEYMOUTH
dialogues.text: It was our quartermaster.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (not breaking his stride) Quiet, my dear - you were in Poona at the time. I remember this -

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: (his mouth agape as he still looks at Jekyll vacuously) But look here, Jekyll - I mean I - I simply must get this straight - you mean -?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY 52
dialogues.text: She is trying to get her stupid husband's eye to keep him from pressing the subject.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (warmed to his subject, glad of the interest) Well, to put it as simply as I can - Good and evil are so close as to be chained together in the soul. Man isn't truly one, but two. Now what if we could break that chain - separate those two selves -- (his face alight, lost in his subject) To free the good in man, and let it go on to its higher destiny... to segregate the bad in man - and let it destroy itself in its own degradation! (looks around, sees he has gone beyond their comprehension - finishes lamely) Well, roughly that's what my research is leading to -- a combination of chemical agents, which if administered would -- Marley has just awakened to the fact that his guests aren very happy - particularly the two nervous ladies on his e side. Also, he feels his own "character" attacked.

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: (sputtering) But see here - aren't you rather presumptuous in assuming there is evil in all men?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Of course there's evil in all men! He speaks the following with a peculiar faunlike glee, ja at them with his tone, quietly, but watching them all as looks around the table. He's mad now at their subborn ref to look at the facts.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW
dialogues.text: Jekyll's voice comes over the stiff-lipped women and uncomfortable men. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We'd be hypocrites if we didn't admit it. We've all had thoughts we wouldn't care to have published ... or shouted out loud. Our desires aren't always confirmed to a drawing room. As Christian we admit that Man was created weak! It's an honest problem. Shouldn't we face it? By this time WE HOLD ON the Bishop. There is a tense sile

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: (with gentle dignity) Suppose we believe that Man's soul has not yet reached its fulfillment. Is it right or wise to tamper with this problem, until its Creator has solved it - in His own mysterious way?

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JEKYLL, COLONEL, BISHOP 55
dialogues.text: The Colonel is looking across at Jekyll, trembling with austere indignation.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (softening a little) My Lord - as I said before -

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: He draws himself up in a severe conservative huff.

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Really, Jekyll - this is quite alarming. Such theories are dangerously close to a -- well, I hesitate to think what the Medical Council will be forced to say if --

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JEKYLL'S END OF TABLE 57
dialogues.text: Sir Charles looks with alarm at what Dr. Courtney is sayi

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (with an undercurrent of heat - but smiling) Dr. Courtney - advanced theories are always the sore-point for the Medical Council - or even a Queen's physician. Especially if there's a confortable profit in those already safely established. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (bristling) Jekyll - if -

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (suddenly exploding) If you want my opinion, young man - this is all pure balderdash!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (right back at him) Really, Colonel Weymouth? Suppose we take your profession. What about the soldier when he comes out of battle - keyed up from the lust of killing? What about his thoughts? He's lonely - bewildered. why just recall yourself, as a young subaltern in Egypt - back from a campaign up the Nile - on a moonlit night in Cairo. What were your thoughts? What was in your mind? For a moment the Colonel is so moved by the glamor and nostalgia in Jekyll's words, that his mouth is agape.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (half remembering dim conquests) Well, now - if you put it - I mean that's something diff-- (then suddenly feels his wife's eagle glare - pounds table) Harrumph! By Gad, sir! I've heard enough!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY 58
dialogues.text: She pushes her chair back in the sudden silence, rises wi a sugary little murmur.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARLEY
dialogues.text: Ladies...?

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 59
dialogues.text: As the ladies rise, and leave, the men standing.

dialogues.speaker: LADY COOPER
dialogues.text: (as they go) Oh, I meant to ask. Has anybody seen Wilde's new play, "The Ideal Husband"? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FRENCH
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - at the Haymarket - a little so-so for my taste but then -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. ARNOLD
dialogues.text: The pantomime at the Lane is magnificent. Dan [...] is screamingly funny.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Yes. And have you seen Irving's "King Arthur"... Superb... TwO SHOT - BEATRIX AND JEKYLL (OVER THIS) 60 As she rises she gives him a little smile which means "I' with-you", perhaps even purses her lips at him quickly as WE PAN her away with the other women.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL 61
dialogues.text: He looks after her, raises his eyebrow with a dry grin an shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 62
dialogues.text: He is looking from Jekyll to Beatrix 0.s., a worried look disapproval in his expression, as we,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It clops along with two horses, footman and driver on box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrix sits between Jekyll and Sir Charles on the back s Lanyon sits on the jump seat. Sir Charles looks silent an worried. All are aware of this. WE ONLY HEAR the clop-clo of the horses. Beatrix suddenly puts her hand over her Father's.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (affectionately) Tired, Father darling...?

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Hm? Oh - no, no. (as carriage stops) Well - here we are, eh? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Footman opens door - and Lanyon gets out) That's it. You first, John. (getting out himself with a grunt, as he rises) Hmph! Getting old, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.
dialogues.text: They are in front of Sir Charles' house, a large mansion the period.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Well, Sir Charles, it's been a long evening, so I imagine you -

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, no - no. You must come in for a night-cap, John. (with a smile) If you don't think the rest of the company will be bored with each other. Jekyll and Bee look at each other with relieved smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Well - thank you, sir. Just one. They all move toward the house, as we PAN, and

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM 66
dialogues.text: It is excellently and richly appointed in the style of th period. Some French doors open off into a conservatory to one side. Lanyon is pouring the drinks from a tray. Beatr and Jekyll are across the room at a music box, looking fo some discs. Sir Charles is looking in a humidor for cigar

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL AND BEATRIX 66A
dialogues.text: Jekyll is looking at a disc.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What about this -?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (whispering) No.... this - She looks affectionately o.s. toward her Father. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (puzzled - in same voice) What -?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (whispering) This is the one that makes Father wind his watch. (she puts it on and it starts a lovely waltz)) Look -

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 66B
dialogues.text: He raises his eyes from the humidor at the first strains. seems to think back for a second. THEN WE PAN HIM as he w slowly to grandfather's clock. Beside the clock is a port of a lovely woman, obwiously Beatrix's mother by her look Sir Charles takes out his watch and winds it, but he does not look at it. He is looking up at the picture, not the clock.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 66D
dialogues.text: His eyes are a little misty, as he looks o.s. at the pict TwO SHOT - BEATRIX AND JEKYLL 66E As they watch Sir Charles o.s.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (to Jekyll) It is the waltz that he and Mama first danced together.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (touched) Oh... (turns to Beatrix, with a little bow) May I have the honor, Miss Beatrix?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (curtseying) With pleasure, Dr. Jekyll. He takes her in his arms, and they waltz through the Fren doors into the conservatory.  67 68

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 67
dialogues.text: He turns from the picture and watches them waltz o.s.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES' ANGLE
dialogues.text: They waltz, framed in the French doors.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 68A
dialogues.text: He smiles a little wistfully, touched by his memories.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BEATRIX AND JEKYLL
dialogues.text: They dance o.s. into the part of the conservatory hidden from his view.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 69
dialogues.text: His wistful expression turns to one of worry. Lanyon appe INTO SCENE, carrying two glasses, hands one to Sir Charle

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Sir Charles... (raising his glass) Your health, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Hm? Oh, yes, John - thank you, sir. He raises his glass, then drinks, then looks o.s. toward conservatory again, worried.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX AND JEKYLL
dialogues.text: They are in each other's arms, in a long embrace. WE ARE SHOOTING from the middle of the round, glass-domed room, through ferns and foliage. The waltz plays dimly o.s. The lips part.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Where's our melody - when first we met? We haven't got any.... They start walking around the rotunda and WE PAN.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, yes we have. It isn't when you meet. It's when you know.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Know what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stops They kiss 34. 70

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: That the world's spinning around - just for two people alone.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: When do two people know a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh... just about a month ago - ona high hill in Scotland...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I know that hill... Pretty close to Heaven, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Right there. Right on the outskirts....

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (as though suddenly remembering) I was there about that time - witha girl of all things!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Was the heather very high - and the clouds very low above their heads -?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Hmmm - yes - but what I remember most was the way the wind caught the absurd little ringlets in her hair. (touching around her ear) Right about there. and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: See? That's our melody.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nodding) Uh-hm. again. She looks at him a second, then draws away and starts fingering a flower.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Harry...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What?  71

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX 71
dialogues.text: As she turns and looks up at him searchingly.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL 71A
dialogues.text: As he looks at her, wondering at her look.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What, Bee?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (slowly) T) Onight at dinner... I understand what you said about good and evil in people - and that it's that way in all of us... but if good and evil are so Closely related in us - chained, as you said - why isn't -?. (then she stops with a little laugh, and a shake of her head, turning from him - fingering flower again) Oh, no - it sounds so... silly - and wrong, even...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (tenderly) This is you and I. Remember us? Nothing you and I can ever discuss will be wrong....

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Well then, why - why isn't the way you and I feel about each other -? I mean... (hesitates, then with direct, serious warmth) There's nothing evil in that, is there? Jekyll laughs tenderly, and takes her hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Look here. You and I are in love. Such a small word for such a great thing! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But whatever it is, it's a blessed thing, Bee. It makes us one strong, living soul. And it takes whatever power - or even whatever secret delight that there is in evil - and turns it all into good. (searching her eyes) Do I have to tell you that....?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, no -! She surges into his arms. They kiss passionately, then lo at each other, speechless for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (suddenly) What in the world are we doing? Here we are -- bound hand and heart in some ridiculous long engagement -- just because it's the conventional correct thing to --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, I know, my darling - I don't want to wait, either. Let's ask Father if --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: You leave it to me. I'll take him to the club - put a glass of his favorite brandy in his hand and when I'm through he'll -- They both turn as WE HEAR footsteps o.s. Sir Charles appe carrying a glass in his hand. The music has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (as he approaches) Help John, will you, my dear? He's in there hunting for the Bonnie Banks of Loch Lommond, or something -

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Father... She goes past him. Jekyll starts to follow.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Harry...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir Charles? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: I'm not one to brood about and all that -- but you must have noticed my attitude coming home this evening.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Why, sir - I merely thought that -

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: That amazing flight of fancy you put forth at dinner... I must confess it startled me -- and even though I'ma broad-minded man, myself -- it was a little shocking, too...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, Sir Charles - because I assure you it wasn't a flight of fancy at all.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: You mean you actually were in earnest?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Profoundly so, sir. In fact, I'm arranging to spend all my time at it --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: This is distressing, Harry --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (puzzled at his attitude) Why?

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: It's absolutely hair-brained, in my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (a little stung) I'm sorry you feel that way. I've just been explaining it further to Bee. She understands.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (stiffening - but in gentle reminder ) There are some things no gentlewoman should understand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, come now, sir. In this day and age we're surely getting beyond all that sort of -- (breaking off) Besides, Bee and I are adults, sir - we're deeplyin love - and very close. That's why we see no need to wait. We want to be married as soon as possible. We both feel that --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: I thought we decided on February.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But that's months away! We need each other now. I want her near me - with me - in all the work I'm going to --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: No, no, Harry - I can't discuss any change in the plans. After this evening, more than -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But, Sir Charles --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Harry! Restraint is wise and healthy in all matters... A sort of proving ground. I waited five years for Beatrix's mother.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (with a wry smile) If you'll forgive me, sir -- you were a very sturdy man.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (laughing) Well, I'm not asking that of you - but, come now, Harry. I'we always wanted a son - and now you're going to be that. So listen to me, my boy. You're a coming man in your profession. I'm proud of you. But these ridiculous experiments won't get you anywhere. You must give them up. Develop your practise. Cultivate the circle in which you and Beatrix shall move. That's common sense, my boy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (patting his shoulder) There now. I've had my say. Let's get your night-cap, hm? Getting late. He turns and starts back into drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, don't forget - I've taken a box for the opening concert at the Albert Hall - (passes o.s. ahead of Jekyll) You and John will join us, of course... But Jekyll is hardly listening, he is moody and downcast, and almost resentful, as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SIR CHARLES' HOUSE 74
dialogues.text: Lanyon and Jekyll are just coming down the steps and turn into the walk along the street as WE PAN AND TRUCK with t Jekyll is silent and moody.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (noticing his mood) What's up? You and the old boy cross swords?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (dryly) ; It seems that I should give up my research - and carry on with taking out little Reggie Smith's adenoids and giving Lady Gwendolyn St. Clair a sugar pill for her perennial self- induced hysteria - or else encounter the serious disapproval of Bee's father.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, it can't be that bad, Harry. But you did cut up a bit rough at the Marley's, you know. Jekyll stops, turning to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (a little sharply) I'm not asking you to agree with me. I just have a decision to make, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Now, look, Harry - you and I have been friends for years. I can't agree with your theories - but that needn't break up our friendship, you know. I haven't seen anything of you lately. (taking his arm) Come on - let's drop down to the club and play a rubber of whist. Do you good.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (moodily) I'll walk that far with you...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL AND LANYON

dialogues.text: Let me go, you -! Why you filthy -! Help -! Jekyll and Lanyon both look down the mews, then dart o.s. toward the sound.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Let him go. Get a cab. I'll see what's been done. He hurries back into the mews. 78 TwO SHOT - JEKYLL AND GIRL 78 She is sitting on the rubbish box, straightening her hat muttering to herself in comic tearfulness as Jekyll appro into SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (to herself) A nice thing... when a girl can't... the big...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: dusting off her dress - hardly noticing him) It'd take more than a bloke like that to -- (suddenly sees him for first time, impressed by his looks and attire, in almost childish admiration) Oh..! (straightening her hat) I'll bet I look ever so untidy. Jekyll can't help but smile, amused by her reaction. Then

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: You're sure you're not hurt?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Why... I don't think so - I - (stands - winces on one foot) Oo!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Ankle?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Mm. Twisted. (sways and catches his arm) Do you mind? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Of course not. An ankle can be very painful...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You're ever so kind. (feeling her side) Mm! Me side, too. He bashed a rib, he did!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have stopped. I should have caught him, eh?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I mean - I'm so glad you stopped - if you take my meaning.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nodding ahead) My friend's getting a cab. Can we drive you anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You're ever so kind.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Let's try it, shall we? (they start to walk toward end of mews as WE TRUCK WITH THEM. She limps) That's the girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (smiling up at him) A gent like you shouldn't be bothering yourself about me, now.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What sort of a gent doesn't like to help a pretty girl? Hm? He says this with casual politeness, but smiles down at h as he finishes.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: ... and so he asks me can he walk me home, he does. And I says yes. When a girl has to work late at nights, it's nice to have a bit of company to see you home...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (pleasantly, as Lanyon makes no remark) Naturally.

dialogues.text: (now all to Jekyll) I know what's what. You have to if you're a barmaid. I like a bit of fun, as the saying goes. dialogues.text: Ow! It hurts more now -!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Here - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: It is the usual dingy rooming house chamber, appointed as the era and the girl.... cheap souvenirs - men's pictures (sailors and soldiers) tacked unframed on the walls, etc. Jekyll puts his hat and stick down on a chair, and then c the door. WE PAN him over to her as she looks up at him, half shy, half excitedly expectant.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (calmly) You better let down your blouse.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (a little "miffed" at the calm approach) Why?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (easily) Don't you want me to have a look at you?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (coyly) ; ; I don't know. You're lookin', ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But, your side. I thought you -- Then with a giggle, she quickly peels off her blouse, (or lets down her shirt-waist) revealing herself in a fluffy thin top slip of the period. She looks up at him, trying "play up". She pulls her feet upon the bed, under her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (softly) You aren't half a fast one, aren't you? Jekyll looks puzzled for a second, then bursts out laughi They stop He smiles turn away.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (between chuckles) I'm sorry. Let's both understand this, shall we? My friend and I are physicians.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Physicians...?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nodding) Doctors.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Doctors? (suddenly laughs delightedly at the situation) Go on! I thought you were just a couple of toffs!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (laughing, too) No. Haven't the leisure.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (throwing back her head, laughing) Oh, dear me! -- And here I thought -! laughing and look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (quickly, easily again) Well, I'm glad to see you're not really hurt... down at her, with a chiding look, then starts to

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh, but I am, Doctor - truly - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (still kidding, turning back) I better send you to the hospital, hm?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (offering her side) No, look - here - feel - Jekyll adopts a mock serious manner and feels her side.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Here -?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: ("wincing") O-o! Yes -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Hm - I thought so - a transossis pactoralis...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (puzzled, alarmed) What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (into her eyes) That means your eyes are twin pools of desire...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (softly, slowly, charmed) Aw, Doctor... that's neat. You can say the words, you can..!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: ("surprised") But doesn't this still hurt? She looks down to see he is prodding her side.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (quickly, wincing) Hm? Oh - yes - 0-0 -!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (straightening up, with a chuckle) It'll be all right in the morning... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She quickly kicks off her shoe, peels off her stocking, h the garter in her hand, a little rubber-tape ringlet with gew-gaw buckle.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (as she does so, softly) But look here - my ankle - don't you think you ought to look at that?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (smiling, shaking his head) No. (then points to where garter has left a red mark above her knee) But I'll tell you one thing, young lady. You wear that garter too tight. Bad. Stops the circulation. The girl looks down and then looks up at him, patheticall happy that he is this solicituous about her at least. She rises and grabs his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: There! You see now? You did find something. You are my doctor, aren't you? (as he only smiles at her, then: ) I ought to pay you a fee...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (a little caught) I haven't presented any bill...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (handing him garter) How about this? To begin with... (as he looks at it) Not that it's enough.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Some people don't pay half as much --

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: It don't seem near enough to me -! With this she puts her arms about his neck and kisses him He half returns the embrace.  49.

dialogues.text: The door opens with a simultaneous knock, and Lanyon stan there.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Harry -? Is this -? (seeing them break apart) Oh... sorry - (a little coldly) Come along, will you? It's getting late. He turns and we HEAR him walk down steps o.s.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL AND JEKYLL 128B
dialogues.text: He looks after Lanyon, frowning a little, then chuckles t himself and shakes his head. He picks up his hat and stic walks toward the door. The girl follows him. He automatic puts garter in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (puzzled) You - you ain't really goin' - just because he says that -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: No. But I have to go -

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: But, look here - don't you understand? I ain't no--

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (warmly) I know that. You're a girl with her heart just where it ought to be - it's just a little too generous, that's all. (patting her arm) -- So because you're a nice pretty girl - just be a little smarter about the company you pick from now on. Hm - why not?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Well, but -- You're here, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be, though. If you knew me, you'd know I really don't want to be. You see -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 128B CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl lifts her head quickly, stung.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh! Well, I picks only them as wants my company. I'll tell you that! Her lip starts to quiver. Whatever her carefree loves, sh senses she is the woman scorned. Her eyes start to flash.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (knowing it is useless to make her understand) I'm sorry. It's my fault. I should have --

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Whatcha sorry about? I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (one last try) Come, now. Let's say we wore both foolish and it was all in fun - and wish each other luck the next time we take a drink, hm? As he says this, he puts out his hand. She ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (starts to laugh) I suppose it was all in fun when you kissed me?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Yes. I have it coming to me, my dear. (going out door) But anyhow - good night and good luck. Always.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (slamming door on him) You wasn't all in fun then - I know that! She starts laughing, tears of rage in her eyes. 129-133 OUT.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He hears her laughing.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Next time you look at a girl, make up your mind, mister! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shakes his head again, wondering how he got in the who mess, and starts down the stairs.

dialogues.text: Lanyon is sitting quietly looking ahead. Jekyll is studyi him, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (finally) Oh come now, John - don't get that stuffy look. The lady wasn't injured, and neither was I - nor anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: I admit she might be a tempting little trick - in an off moment.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What do you mean.. "off moment"?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (sardonically) Yours. According to your theory, I imagine that graphic tableau I just witnessed was the momentary triumph of the evil in your soul over the good. Correct?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (after a second's thought) Why...yes. Not quite a triumph... (with a serious little smile) But it was an attack. (then quickly) - yet one that would have been repulsed without your presence, John, I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you run less personal risk if you confined your experiments to your laboratory? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Well, the laboratory's where you'll find me from tonight on - (looking ahead, almost to himself) until I get what I'm looking for... Lanyon notices his determined look, shrugs with a little shake of his head, as we

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She thinks for a second, then quickly gets out of bed, hu to the closet as WE PAN and starts pulling out some attir as we

dialogues.speaker: FRONT HALL
dialogues.text: Beatrix, now dressed, tip-toes down the stairs and silent opens the door to the street.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: The burner is now off. Jekyll is pouring the contents, wh have dripped from the retort into a container, from the container into a vial. It smokes and swirls strangely. He holds the vial a second. He looks at the letter to Beatri leaning in a prominent position on the table.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL AT MIRROR 142
dialogues.text: Holding the vial, he examines his face, feels his skin, turning his head. He starts to raise the vial to his lips Then he gets another thought. WE PULL BACK AND PAN LEFT A RIGHT IN LONG SHOTS as he puts vial back on table, runs t the drapes at the back of the lab, pulls them to, over th windows, then dashes up the stairs and locks the door. He comes down again, approaches the vial, slowly, picks it u For a moment, he looks straight ahead into the CAMERA, as though into the future. Then down the vial with one long gulp. For a second, nothing happens. Then he grips his th in a violent convulsion, he chokes, groans, and gags. He hardly breathe. Slowly, his face starts to change into a haggard and horrible caricature of himself. He spins arou a couple of times, then falls to the floor, writhing. THE CAMERA ZOOMS down into his body, and is blacked out, as w

dialogues.text: These to show the tortured metamorphosis in the splitting Jekyll's soul: In a spinning maelstrom of odd mechanical whirring sounds, rasping and cacophonous noises and odd s come the faces and voices of the following: 1. Heath's Voice: "I can't allow it, Jekyll." 2. Mrs. Weymouth's Voice: "Vicious - filthy - indecent." 3. Jekyll's Voice: "... and let it destroy itself in its degradation." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A142 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 150 4. Courtney's Voice: "... I hesitate to say what the Medi Council would..." 5. Beatrix's Voice: "There's nothing evil in that, is the 6. It ends in a weird sighing moan and far away laughter, as

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: His back is to the CAMERA (or is it Jekyll?). We ask as W PAN UP WITH HIM, his back like an animal's in a crouch. T top of his head is strangely elongated, his ears are poin As yet we do not see his face but FOLLOW HIM as he slowly shuffles, gasping and grunting to the mirror. There over shoulder, we get a look at his face for the first time. I is hideous in its transformation into Evil, yet withal containing a strange fascinating Pan-like quality. At fir he starts, as though an animal looking in the mirror for first time. Then he peers closer. And he starts to laugh, slowly, softly at first, then mounting to loud yelps.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (into mirror - like eyeing a work of great art) Look at you... look at you... what beautiful consumate evil! (shouting exultantly) There you are! And I made you! What a rainbow of unspeakable colors could you paint the world's horizon if I turned you loose! (laughs louder, triumphantly now) There it is, Sir Charles! Look at it, John Lanyon! Show this to the Medical Council, Dr. Courtney!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (continued) Hypocrites! Fools! Blind men! Deny what's in your souls, will you? You can't deny that! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then WE PAN HIM as he capers about the room, leaping and stretching and jumping up and down like a faun, laughing the time. 0.s. there is a knock on the door which he does hear.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAB
dialogues.text: Inside the laughter comes over the SCENE. Poole, in his dressing gown, is listening. He reacts to laughter, then starts banging on the door, trying to open it.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (in great alarm) Dr. Jekyll - Dr. Jekyll! What's happening, sir? Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He stops capering as he hears the banging on the door, al as a wild animal.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Eh? Who's there? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: POOLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's Poole, sir! Dr. Jekyll - is that you, sir? The banging continues. Jekyll looks wildly about, then se vials on the table. He hurriedly starts mixing them in an potion.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Just a moment, now!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: When he hears the silence, he gets even more worried.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Who is that in there? Dr. Jekyll - answer me, sir! Dr. Jekyll --! He shoves his weight against the door, cannot budge it, t starts o.s. toward the house when he is called back by footsteps on the stairs. He waits a little warily, as the come toward the door. The door opens quickly. Dr. Jekyll stands there, his natural self. He is pale, perspiring, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (trying to be calm) Yes, Poole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (stammering) Why, sir - I - I'm sorry, sir - I heard a frightful noise -and a strange voice - and - and I thought something had happened, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: No... it was quite - all right, Poole. There was someone here. He - he was a friend of mine. A - er - a... Mr. Hyde. He was a bit - well, under the weather - rather obstreperous. I got him out by the back door.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, sir. (then, back to the servant again) Miss Beatrix is here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (hit between the eyes) Miss Beatrix.... alone?

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (re-assuringly) I've shown her to the consulting room, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Tell - tell Miss Beatrix I shall be there at once.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. Jekyll closes the door, as Poole exits o.s.

dialogues.speaker: LAB 154
dialogues.text: Jekyll comes down the stairs in the b.g. He is stunned by this announcement from Poole. Mechanically, dazed, he sta putting on his tail coat. Then with a sudden rush of thou as WE PAN, he rushes to the mirror again, examines his fa to see if any of the awful evil is left. He feels his che his brow, his ear. He covers his face with his hand, in revulsion at what he had seen earlier. Then he looks at himself again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (muttering through his teeth some dim remembered quotation) "... if once this thing is born again, Decapitate it - e're it fouls the air..." Then he quickly turns from the mirror, crosses and picks the letter he has written Beatrix, tears it into small pi throws it in the waste-basket, and adjusting his coat, st up the stairs. Half way up he hesitates, then proceeds mo slowly, as we

dialogues.speaker: INT. JEKYLL'S CONSULTING ROOM
dialogues.text: The room is much as we would expect... a desk, consultati chair, many shelves of medical books, a few standard instruments in a case. Beatrix is seated, nervous and anx She turns quickly, as Jekyll opens the door from the hall in the b.g. Jekyll's attitude is one of hesitancy at firs as though awaiting some feared reaction from her.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (quickly) Then you're not -? Harry, what's the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on this she is starting over towards him, then stops, looking at him - his attitude is tense, strained as though she knew something. Then she gives hima puzzled little smile, feels her temple) I can't explain why... but I hada strange feeling you were going away - without ever seeing me again isn't that silly? (she slowly sinks down in a chair, looks about the room, then up at him with an embarrassed, nervous little laugh) It - it was silly, wasn't it? Because here you are - and here I am... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (feeling he must say something) I had to go to the hospital, Bee.... the man died.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry... maybe that's what I felt. But it was just something that -- (then, with another little laugh) Why - I had no reason to come at all! She rises again, automatically. Jekyll takes her hand wit sudden gesture.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Bee - yes!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (with a soft smile) You're glad I'm here then? Jekyll sweeps her into his arms. Holds her almost despera close. In this gesture, her cape falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Glad? I'd have come to you, I think - if you hadn't -- I mean - tonight, somehow, I missed you more than ever...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (her lips against his cheek) When I'm in this house, I won't let you waste your nights in that stuffy old laboratory... You know that, don't you - hmmm...?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) You'll never be out of sight -! He holds her for a second, then:

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (turning her face to his) I don't want to go home....

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Bee.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: You said it wasn't evil for us to -- please, don't send me away now.... He looks full in her eyes for a second, then they kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (ecstatic) Oh, my love -! (then she stops, and withdraws from him a little, as her eyes catch something o.s. Jekyll turns too. Beatrix's chin lifts in defiance. Then, quietly: ) Yes, Father....? WE PAN OVER slowly to pick up Sir Charles standing in the open door-way. Behind him in the hall is Poole, nervously wringing his hands. Poole ducks o.s., as Sir Charles come slowly into the room, as WE PAN, and confronts Beatrix an Jekyll. Without a word, he leans down, picks up Beatrix's cape and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (in a quiet, cold voice to Jekyll) I am very grateful for the anxiety you caused us this evening - (to Beatrix) I was unable to sleep myself.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Sir Charles, I asked Beatrix to come here tonight --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (reproving him) Harry - you --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (to Sir Charles) Because I --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (to Jekyll) Apparently you didn't consider our talk the other evening very seriously? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Sir Charles, I beg to believe that there was no --

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: All I can believe is that your theories of behavior are not normal, Jekyll -- not fit. I might say not even --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (interrupting quickly) Father, I don't expect you to understand. I'm not ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Then I shall be for you... because I do understand. You and I are leaving for the Continent tomorrow. We shall be catching the afternoon boat-train.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (stunned) The Continent? Oh, come, sir -- there's --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (pleading now) Oh, Father, please -!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (trying to reason) Sir Charles - you could avoid all of this misunderstanding if you'd set an early date for our marriage.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Please, Father....

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: The date remains as planned. (to Jekyll) And if you haven't abolished those unhealthy experiments of yours - (as Jekyll starts to speak) Oh, I know you're still working at them - why, we'll consider the engagement broken.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: swear to you, sir, I've finished entirely with everything that I - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: That will await our return. Come, Beatrix.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (to Jekyll) Harry - if you don't wish me to go away - I shall refuse.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (sternly) Beatrix -!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: I mean it, Father. She turns to Jekyll for an answer. He looks at her for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (finally) I don't want you to go away, Bee. But - even though you and I can't agree with him - your Father is only thinking of your happiness. I can't disrespect him in that. I can't ask you to. There is a moment of silence. Beatrix sees that Jekyll me it.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (with a relieved sigh, more gently now) That's highly commendable, Harry. Beatrix now tries to smile. She offers her hand to Jekyll

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (fighting tears) You - you'll see us off at the train?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (taking her hand - nodding) It better have two engines - or I'll try to hold it back.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Try anyway. She goes close to him, kisses his cheek swiftly, and with little sob, turns and hurries out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (more kindly) Restraint, my boy - restraint. It's the only strength of human existance.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Sir Charles.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Goodnight. He turns and follows Beatrix. Jekyll looks after them, miserable, as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JEKYLL'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is raining, a heavy driving rain.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JEKYLL'S LAB
dialogues.text: Jekyll stands looking out of the back windows, leaning up against the wall. Poole enters from the stair landing and comes down carrying a tray on which is a letter and a gla of sherry wine. Jekyll does not even look around.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: At bottom of stair, he stops and looks at Jekyll o.s.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He is moody and disconsolate, as he looks at the rain out

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: He shakes his head, frowning, then smiles to himself as W PAN HIM OVER to Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (gently) How about a glass of sherry wine, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (without looking) No, thank you, Poole - no sherry wine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Well, would you consider a letter - ah - from Aix Les Bains? Jekyll turns quickly, his face lighting up.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (snatching up letter) Poole, you blackguard! Would I? (tears open letter, Poole starting to move away with the tray) And your sherry wine, too - what's more! Poole comes back and gives glass to Jekyll. Jekyll starts reading letter avidly, holding wine in his hand. Poole mo 0.s.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE 167
dialogues.text: As he comes to a desk, and starts straightening things up He wants to talk, to cheer his master up.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Miss Beatrix should be returning home in another week, shouldn't she, sir? Hobson told me they were expected. He gets no answer from Jekyll o.s. He turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Jekyll's expression is turning from interested delight to puzzlement. Then his face clouds entirely. He puts glass down on window-sill. It falls over with a tinkle and a sp Jekyll quickly turns the page, anguished.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX'S LETTER
dialogues.text: (LINES ARE FROM TOP OF PAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... did not write yesterday because I'm so distressed. Darling heart - Father - refuses to come home. We are lea tomorrow for Italy - to be gone I don't know how long. Oh my dearest, if you knew how I've tried to.."

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 170
dialogues.text: Poole sees Jekyll's concern and rage, as Jekyll looks awa from the letter. Poole advances to him, to pick up glass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Not bad news, I hope, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Miss Beatrix will be gone indefinitely - that's all.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, sir. Sir Charles' health, no doubt. (a pause, as Poole watches Jekyll slump down in a chair) If you'll forgive me, sir - it distresses me to see you down this way. It's not right, sir. Might I suggest that you pick up and go out this evening for a bit of fun? They say there's a very entertaining musical comedy at the Gaiety - (with a little cough) - er - ah -, very daring, you know, sir - Jekyll considers this a moment, looking at Poole. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (dryly) ; I'm afraid that's not particularly becoming in my position, Poole - (then with a sardonic chuckle) ) Nor even wise, I might add.... He rubs his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Another glass of sherry wine, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (face in his hands, wearily) No thank you, Poole...

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Poole exits from scene, with tray and broken glass. We he him go upstairs 0.s. and close the door. Then Jekyll gets with sudden impatience. Doesn't find it. H walks over by the cabinet.  171 172 173 174 70.

dialogues.speaker: IVY'S GARTER 172
dialogues.text: It is still where Jekyll must have tossed it weeks ago. I cheap little clasp, glistens in the lamplight.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL 173
dialogues.text: Fascinated, he slowly bends over and picks it up. He feel it in his hand. He thinks of the girl. Then he quickly th it on the table. WE PAN HIM as he paces the length of the room again, nervously. This brings him opposite the mirro He looks at himself then thinks, looks back at the garter then over at a cabinet. Then he makes his decision, and hurries to the cabinet, pulling out some vials of powders and liquids from various pigeon-holes. As he hastily carr them to the lab table and sits himself down to mix them,

In violent convulsions, his face starts to turn. grips the sides of the chair in agony. WE PAN DOWN to his hand. It turns into an animal-like appendage. His four fi seem to grow together a little bit at the base, and then separate in the middle, almost like the beginning of a cl hoof. His neck becomes thick and shorter. WE PAN UP to his face. It is worse than before. WE PAN DO to the other hand. The same process is happening here. He gasping and writhing all the while. WE PAN UP again to hi face. The transformation now becomes complete. It is wors in this second stage - more bestial than faun. His writhi stops. He rises, shakes his head - feels the change in hi thoughts. dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (on track, whispering) It's in your eyes - it's in your eyes... He hurries over to the mirror to look. He is truly this M Hyde now, whom he spoke about to Poole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (into mirror, gleefully) Yes, Mr. Hyde! Wonderful, Mr. Hyde! It is! You are the modern Narcissus! Your face reflects man's Eternity as it was meant to be! He leaps away from the mirror, stretches himself like an animal in the middle of the room, thinks again.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (whispering) (with a low laugh) Caught, aren't you? You're caught...

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (suddenly, exultantly) No! I'm free! Free! He capers about a second, then quickly takes his cape, st and hat from a hanger, and darts out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He takes a key out of his pocket, and locks the door. The he turns and looks about him. He takes off his hat and stretches again in the rain, looking up into the elements Then he darts off into the darkness as we

dialogues.speaker: INT. ROOMING HOUSE HALL 176
dialogues.text: We are SHOOTING TOWARD front door on which somebody is ba furiously on the outside. The slatternly landlady hurried comes down the steps, opens door. She jumps back with a startled cry as Hyde barges in.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (his eyes agleam) Is she here? Is she in?

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: (back up stairs a way) Who? Who do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (pointing) The dove - the little white dove that nests in her warm loft up there?

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: (as he starts up steps) If it's Ivy Pearson you want - she - she ain't in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (thinking over the name) (coming down) Ivy, eh? Ivy... (with a sly laugh poking her with stick) Clinging, no doubt, too.... (then, impatiently) Come, come - you leaf of jaded lettuce! Where is she? Where does she work?

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: At the Palace of Varieties!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Ah! At the Palace of Varieties! What a shallow hearth for the fire of my lovely jewel! (then, cocking his head to one side) But - variety, eh? Variety! I like that! With a caper, he pokes the landlady in her backside with stick, and dashes out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: CURB
dialogues.text: Hyde comes out, gleeful at the prospect of finding Ivy. H comes abreast of an old blind man who is timidly tapping stick on the curb, preparatory to crossing the street. Hy takes his arm with exaggerated solicitation.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Why, why! Let me give you a hand, Uncle!

dialogues.speaker: BLIND MAN
dialogues.text: (with a happy smile) Oh...thank you, sir! WE TRUCK AHEAD OF THEM across the street. They weave thei way past a couple of drays. Then, in the middle of the st Hyde kicks the old man's stick out from under him.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (laughing gleefully) There you are, Uncle - safe and sound! (CONTINUED)

177 The old man exclaims inarticulately - "Here - no - no -" gropes about for his stick which Hyde flicks farther away along the cobbles with his own. A cart nearly runs the ol man down, the driver pulling reels backwards. Hyde utters HIM as he crosses the street where a cab is standing near

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: As he climbs into hansom, he up with a jerk as the old man another happy laugh, and WE PAN and capers down the walk to the intersection of a neuse. 178 taps the nodding driver with his stick.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Come, come - my dozing fungus -! (as Cabbie wakes up quickly) To the Palace of Varieties!

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Right, sir!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (wacking horse's right rump with cane) Right, sir! (then whacking left) Left, sir! (then whacking center) And a bit down the middle, sir! Naturally, the horse leaps to action during this as WE PA

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PALACE OF VARIETIES 179
dialogues.text: It is the facade of the average cheap music hall of the period. Hyde leaps out of the cab as it comes to a stop. looks at the place with eager interest, then turns to han the Cabbie his fare. As the latter reaches down for the m Hyde has the sudden caprice to pull him tumbling off his seat, rolling him on the pavement. Hyde throws the money top of him and then pokes him with his stick.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (capering about) Whee! All the king's horses and all the king's men! A couple of hangers-on in front rush up. A passer-by stop (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 1ST HANGER-ON
dialogues.text: (as though to detain Hyde) Here, here, Guv'nor - what's the -? Hyde turns and raises his stick, with a growl of rage. Th men jump back, scared at the expression of viciousness th see. Then Hyde chuckles, and darts on into the music hall box office, as we

dialogues.speaker: INT. PALACE OF VARIETIES 180
dialogues.text: A smoke-filled Utopia with a bar at one end, a stage at t other. Along the side, boxes with tables and chairs - and tables and chairs ranging on an incline from the stage ba towards the bar. The "chairman" at his table down front i conducting the proceedings on the stage, a row of plump soubrettes in a song and dance ensemble to the tune of "Champagne Charlie". WE SEE Hyde come in in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 181
dialogues.text: He comes in, stands a moment, smelling the wind like an expectant ram. A waiter approaches him, sees his quality attire. Hyde hands him his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, sir - Box F, sir. WE PAN THEM through the tables and up some small steps ar in back of a box which Hyde enters. The waiter stands, expecting an order, as Hyde's eyes dart about, savoring t place. The waiter is now a little leery of Hyde's looks a wants to please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: A brandy and soda, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (with a grunt, nodding his head) Hmph. The waiter exits. Hyde continues to sweep the room with h look.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Hyde's glance travels about slowly, enjoying each group. HOLDS at a table where a young man is kissing the neck of his girl friend. She pretends to repulse him.  183 184 185 186 187 75.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 183
dialogues.text: He likes this. He shifts happily in his chair. He looks t the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF SOUBRETTES
dialogues.text: We travel down the line of hard-working young ladies. The lift their limbs in a sort of can-can.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 185
dialogues.text: This pleases him no end. He lifts his stick and rotates i like the limbs of the girls. The waiter appears with the brandy and soda, puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (elaborately) Yes, sir. Hyde picks up the glass, starts to drink, and just then notices something o.s. His eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: HIS ANGLE
dialogues.text: She is behind the bar, laughing and joking with two or th men. The reason Hyde can see her is that she is standing a stool, reaching up for a bottle at the back of the bar, she looks back at the men below. We cannot hear what she saying, naturally.
