dialogues.text: (with a chuckle) It'll be a knife in your heart. Won't it? On this, he snicks a grape skin right into the curly hair about her temple. It sticks there. She tries to laugh, as she picks it out. Then she quickly gets up and exits from SCENE, taking cards with her as Hyde watches her.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: As she comes to a cabinet and starts to put cards away, staying there to re-arrange things just for something to

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He watches her, smiling, swinging one leg as he sits on t table, munching more grapes.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: And what would my little cherub like to do this evening?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: She turns - a plea in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, sir! Could we go out, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Out? You mean - gad about a bit? See the sights?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: She comes over to him, hopeful of selling him the idea.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. You'd like it, wouldn't you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Well, now, that might be very pleasant - yes - let's see - where shall we go? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, they say the Alhambra and such places is ever so nice.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: They do? Who does?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Well, Marcia, sir. She says it's ever so gay.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We can go, can't we, sir? They say the entertainment is ever such fun. And I - well, I haven't been out in so long, I -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: You are getting somewhat pale, my dear...

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: It's true, sir. Not that I'm complain ing, you understand - but-

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (gently) Oh, I know. You're just jumpy - nervous - that's it.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: You have that - that cooped-up feeling...

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. You do understand, don't you? Then we'll -?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (with a sudden idea) I know! What about Albert Hall? To a symphony, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Symphony, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles 97.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (with scorn) Yes - where all the toffs go - when they're respectable. When they'd rather tell a girl her garter's too tight than to say what's really in their thoughts -!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (a little crestfallen) Well, sir - I sort of hoped we could - (stops, looks at him a little puzzled as the word "garter" rings in her past unconscious mind) What makes you say -?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (quickly - gaily) So you want to go out, eh?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (thinking this his assent) Oh, yes, sir! I'll go put on my things and -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (sweetly) We're not going!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (turning back to him) Sir -?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (mimicking her) Because the entertainment is ever so gay and nice right here! at her evilly, chuckles a little. She turns away with a sudden desperate gesture, putting both hands over brow.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (gently) Now we've got to think of what we'll do, don't we? (as she says nothing) Let's see shall we play cards? No, you're probably tired of cards -- (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivy turns break. 98.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as she still stands, her face covered) You could read to me, couldn't you? Milton's Paradise Lost would be nice - but we haven't the book here - and you don't know it from memory, do you? (suddenly) Oh! I know. You remember what we like! (leaning over toward her softly) Sing to me... slowly. Her eyes widen in horror. She starts to

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (with a sudden sob) Oh, no - please, sir - not that -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Not in good voice -?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: It isn't that, sir. It -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (in sweet reproof) Why! It's such a pretty song!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (wringing her hands, starting to sob) Oh, please, sir - not tonight!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Sing it gaily!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: I - I can't - truly -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (his tempo accelerating) Then softly - with compassion...

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Please, sir - if you'll just do me the favor -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: With loving kindness even... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (sobbing more - terrified now) Don't ask me to - please, sir -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Then moodily. That's it - with deep mood!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, sir - whatever you like - but for the love of -! With a lightning-like movement, his gentle taunting turns a fierce, vicious command as he pinches her chin between thumb and fore-finger. His eyes widen in fury.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: I said sing!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (with almost a scream) But, sir -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Sing it! You hear me? Ivy slowly nods, looks about a little hysterically, backs away a little, as if to an accustomed position before him and pathetically, between sobs, starts to sing a version Champagne Charlie in which she substitutes the words "Champagne Ivy is my name..."

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 205D
dialogues.text: He leans forward on the table, watching her with horrible rising satisfaction, swaying slightly to the music.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: That's it! Smile when you sing! Be gay! Be happy!

dialogues.speaker: IVY 205E
dialogues.text: As she sings, not looking at him, but everywhere else in room that she can. As she finishes she just stands there sobs.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (as she finishes) Bravo! Bravo! A prima donna is born! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's draw her carriage through the streets! Let's shower her with orchids! With this he picks up a bunch of grapes and throws them a her. They smash against her breast, leaving a huge smear. leaps over at her, as WE DOLLY IN CLOSE. His voice is now low and rampant with desire, as he enfolds her in his arm

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Congratulations, my dear!... the world is yours! The moment is Mine -! She tries to pull away from him, but he pulls her in to h savagely, and kisses her. She all but faints under it, an wilts in his arms, her whole body sagging. He looks down her, pulls her arms about his neck, lifts her up, with a look 0.s., as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACK DOOR OF LAB
dialogues.text: Hyde hurries into scene as WE DOLLY IN. He looks left and right, [...], then unlooks the door and ducks in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LAB 208
dialogues.text: Hyde lights gas lamps, then takes off his cape and hat, t quickly goes to [...], picks out a vial, comes to table a pours contents into a glass. He looks about crazily for a second, then drinks it. He gets the same violent reaction from the "outward" phase. He writhes, grips table, etc., the change is much quicker than when he changes to Hyde. Now, before our eyes, he becomes Dr. Jekyll. He seems sag spent. He goes quickly to the mirror and looks at himself as WE DOLLY IN. He peers at, feels, his face anxiously, t looks at his hands. Then he looks at himself in disgust, covers his face with his hands. He paces about a bit, sil berating himself, his lips moving, his fist pounding the table. He takes the back-door key out of his pocket, look at it, then over at the back-door. He makes a firm decisi goes quickly to a small gas smelter, lights it, puts ina chunk of lead, holds the key in his hand, waiting. Sudden there is a knock on the door, o.s., from house.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Jekyll, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh - just a moment, Poole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hurries up the stairs, unlocks the front door, and Poo follows him down stairs. Poole has dressed only in trouse coat and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (relieved) I saw the light. I'm so glad you're back, Dr. Jekyll. I was worried, sir. You'll pardon my appearance.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I was called on an emergency. I stayed at the house.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Oh, Dr. Lanyon called twice today, sir - he said to tell you that Miss Beatrix and her father arrive home in the morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (starting) In the morning?

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (smiling, kindly) I was sure you'd wish to know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (joy mixed with anxiety) Yes... thank you, Poole... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Could I fix you a bite of -?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (quickly) No.... nothing, thank you... nothing...

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (starting upstairs) Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, Poole - first thing tomorrow I want you to get me a special messenger from the district office. I'll give him an envelope to deliver.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (going out door) Yes, sir. Goodnight, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Poole... WE DOLLY INTO JEKYLL as he walks to the smelter. It is no molten hot and reflects on his face. He takes the key and drops it into the boiling lead.

dialogues.speaker: KEY 209
dialogues.text: Dissolving into the molten lead. Jekyll watches it. A gre relief comes over him, and he closes his eyes, lifting hi head, as we FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: INT. IVY'S PARLOR
dialogues.text: Marcia is administering to Ivy's bruises on her shoulders Ivy is sobbing, angry and scared. Freddie, Marcia's gentl friend, stands by quite aghast.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Â» mmm - this is a bad one.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (wincing, between the sobbing) He's a beast, he is -- a dirty beast --

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Rotten shame. Why don't you run away from the filthy beggar?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: What's the use? I tried that once. He found me and -- why he'd kill me if I tried it again! Only last night he --

dialogues.speaker: BUT SHE STOPS... 211
dialogues.text: ...terrified, and they all look toward the door as there a knock on it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (bracing herself) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Special messenger - for Miss Ivy Pearson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (to Freddie) Get it, Freddie. Freddie nods and WE PAN HIM up the steps to the door, whi he opens, showing messenger. Latter hands him the envelop

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Any answer?

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: No, guv'nor. Freddie gives the messenger a coin, and comes down, handi the envelope to Ivy. She opens it, as they watch. She pul out a sheaf of bank notes.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (in wonder) Look here -!

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (picking up and counting notes) I say! Fifty pounds. (looking in envelope) But there's no letter with it. This from him...?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: The blighter must've sent it for what he's done.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Not him - the rotten skinflint - and he don't care nohow...

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (finding a solution, practical) Well - no matter who sent it, it's here. And it's more than enough to get you out of the country.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Jolly good idea! I've got a friend in Paris who'll be only too glad to --

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (jumping up suddenly, a little wildly) No, no! Don't you see? It's a trick - one of his horrible cat-and-mouse tricks - just to torture me! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (starts pacing floor, holding sides of her head with both hands) That's what he hopes I'll do - use it to run away. I can just see his pig eyes thinkin' it up. He'll let me think I've almost got free and then - You don't know him, I tell you! I can't stand it any more, I can't! If I only could do it I'd go down to the river and --! (slumps down in chair again and sobs)

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: It's her nerves, that's what. She ought to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: She ought to see one of thos mental fellers. I know a feller who cured the mater of the vapors or something. I'll go and get the address.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL AND BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Beatrix and Jekyll are seated on a couch. They are holdin hands. He crying. cannot take his eyes from her. Beatrix has been

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: ... but you should have written me. I should be the first to know when you are ill. If I'd known you were that ill I'd have come home at once.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But, Bee darling - don't you see? I knew that and I - I didn't know what to say. I didn't want to worry you... Beatrix wipes away a last tear, and then puts her hand on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, my poor lamb - your face looks so drawn... Jekyll recaptures her hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They kiss, they hear 105. 212

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (a little anxiously) But when you look in my eyes - you see what you've always seen, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (softly, smiling) Yes... I carried that look all over the Continent - locked up inside of me.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (almost like a vow) It will always be there - always.... (then, enfolding her in his arms) Oh, that's what I wanted to hear! And now that you're back, I'll never let you go again. We've got to be married right away, Bee. I can't -- I can't wait all this time...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (gently, pleased by his ardor) Such a wonderful part of love -- to be needed that much...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (seriously) Need you? I need you more than - (breaks off, passes hand over his brow) While you've been gone - it's been -

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (ecstatically) But it's all right now. No more goodbye's for you and me - ever -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (with an excited laugh) That's it! Just Hellos!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Ever and ever. Hello, Dr. Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, Bee -- and then he holds her close. Then they turn as a door closing o.s. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES' VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (cheery) Where's my daughter, Hobson?

dialogues.speaker: HOBSON'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the drawing room, sir. Beatrix and Jekyll rise, Beatrix retains his hand and WE THEM across the room as they meet Sir Charles entering.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (extending his hand) Ah! Well, well, Harry....

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (as they shake hands) I hope I'm welcome again, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Can't think of any reason why you shouldn't be. How've you been? Beatrix read me some of your letters. Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Father, Harry won't admit it. But because he was so upset, he's been very ill while we were away -

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, my boy - feeling fit again?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (grinning) With Bee back, sir? Well!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (bluntly but calmly) And this leads me to speak very plainly, Father. It's in my heart - and I must say it. I want to be married just as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Now, my dear - you know I said that -

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Father, I respect you more than any girl could. But Harry and I - we've waited so long. And if you don't consent, I'll go away with him. I mean it this time. That's how much Harry and I are in love, Father... I'd even hurt you to safeguard it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (hardly believes his ears) Beatrix...!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (impulsively) I swear, sir - you'll never have any regrets.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: It's my whole life, Father. Don't make me hurt you! Isn't my happiness reason enough?

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (after quite a pause, gently) Your happiness is my life, my dear. (with s smile, holding out his arms) All right. Next month it shall be. Beatrix goes into his arms with a glad cry. Sir Charles h her a second, tries to hide a tear. He extends a hand to Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Come to dinner tomorrow, eh, Harry? I should like to make a formal announcement to our friends.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (wringing his hand, inarticulate) Oh, yes, sir - thank you, sir - thank you -!

dialogues.speaker: FOYER
dialogues.text: Jekyll is coming in, by his key.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (calling, as he does so) Poole - Poole -!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (hurrying in) Oh, yes sir! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Poole - look at me - I'm delirious -!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: What, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (flinging him his cape) I should be put in a straight-jacket, Poole! Before I make everybody envious! (putting his hat on Poole's head) But instead I crown you King of the Gypsies - because you shall be the first to know! I'm going to be married, Poole.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (his face lighting up) Oh, splendid, sir. When, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Next month! Next month she'll be in this very house - Mrs. Henry Jekyll! And the walls will turn to cloud banks - and you'll be taking your orders from an angel!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (removing hat) I'm so very glad, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (as we PAN HIM to side door) I must get the call list from the consulting room. You can take it to Sir Charles. He wants it for the invitations.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (following him) There's a patient here, sir - without appointment. Jekyll opens the door to the consulting room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONSULTING ROOM 214
dialogues.text: Jekyll stops full in his tracks, as he sees Ivy sitting t She rises from the chair, her strained and worried expression changing to child-like pleasure and surprise at seeing hi (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Why - why it's you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (behind Jekyll, in explanation) This is Miss Pierson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (strained) Yes... yes, Poole. I'll give you the list later.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. He bows out. Ivy comes slowly toward him.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: So you're the famous Dr. Jekyll? Now, who'd have thought we'd meet again like this? (watches him as he makes no answer) I was the one you and your friend took home that night - remember, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nailed, but striving for calm) Why - oh, yes - yes, of course..

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so glad it's you, sir! You were so kind and good to me that night! Maybe you can --

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: What - ah - what brought you here, Miss Pierson? Ivy is reminded of her plight. With a little sobbing murm she pulls shoulder, and marks. off her coat and slips her shirtwaist off her baring it to him and displaying streaks of welts

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: There, sir! That's what! Look at that! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Jekyll makes no answer, only stares with hypnotized horror at the shoulder) Pretty, ain't it? Did you ever see a thing like that before, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: It's - it's horrible... (then collecting himself, starts for desk) I'll give you some lotion to soothe that. But Ivy stops him quickly. She begins to break down more.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Lotion! It won't be lotions'1ll do the trick, sir! No! It's more than that, sir. I need help, I do! I can't stand it any more! (as Jekyll can only look at her) It's Hyde, sir - a man I know - Mr. Hyde, sir! It's him as done it, and more I can't tell you, sir. He ain't human, he ain't. He's a beast! He won't let me go, sir! And I'm afraid to - I'm afraid to run away.... During this he has slumped down on arm of chair. She cont to explain.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Marcia - she's my girl friend - and Freddie, Mr. Willoughby - he's her friend... they says it's my nerves - and they says as how you know about such things and could help me, sir. (then sinking down on her knees, clinging to him) But, oh sir - I can't bear up no more under it, sir. If - if you can do nothing for me, then give me some poison so I can kill myself.... She breaks down completely now and sobs on his lap. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (in agony - but guarded, too) Why didn't you seek help before? Why didn't you go to the police?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (looking up at him) I tell you I'm afraid, sir! You don't know him, sir. A nice fine gentleman like yourself wouldn't be meeting such a person! He ain't a man - he's a devil! He knows what you're thinking about, he does! Why, if he knows I've been here today, I don't know what he'll do. It won't be nothin' human, I can tell you! Oh, please, sir - please help me. Keep him off -! (in a lower voice, hastily - pleading) I'll do anything you ask, sir - I ain't as bad as you might think -and - and men say as I ain't a bad looker when I'm more myself. You - you liked me once a little, didn't you, sir? And you're really such a fine kind gentleman - honest - that night you walked out of my place, I laughed at you - but I didn't laugh after you'd gone... (averts her head, puts her cheek on his knee) I kept wishin' you'd come back - truly, I did... For a moment, Jekyll stares at her head. And for a flash second, he seems as though he is about to lean over and embrace her with the strange look of Hyde battling for supremacy lifts her in his expression. Then he contains himself and up, as he stands too.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I - I give you my word that you will never be troubled by this man Hyde again.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (sobbing anew) But - but how do you know, sir? He'll come back! He'll come back and kill me, sir! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He'll not come back. I'll see to it.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: But you don't know him, sir. He ain't human, he ain't!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (very strong) I've given you my word - and that I never break. You'll not see Hyde again! (pause, as she looks at him) You must believe me.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (fully convinced) I believe you, sir. I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: You - you must go now.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Yes, sir..... yes, sir. She puts on her coat and goes to the door, then turns.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: She looks at Jekyll o.s., puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: It's funny - but for a moment I thought - (then she stops) Well... goodbye, sir. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL 216
dialogues.text: He reacts to her statement. WE PAN HIM to the mirror wher he examines his face, as we

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REGENT'S PARK
dialogues.text: It is still light, the shadows long. The birds are twitte In the far b.g., through the trees, we see sheep dotting greensward.

dialogues.speaker: PARK ENTRANCE 218
dialogues.text: Mr. Weller, the Park Keeper, is idling about the entrance Jekyll comes gaily into the Park. Jekyll is dressed for t evening, in tails, cape, silk hat and stick.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (hailing him gaily) Mr. Weller, Mr. Weller - good evening! The Park Keeper falls in beside him as we TRUCK WITH THEM

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: Dr. Jekyll! The days keep beautifully long this time of the year.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Beautiful - wonderful! How's little Annie's cough?

dialogues.speaker: PAAK KEEPER
dialogues.text: The medicine you gave her done the trick. She's only whooped twice in a week!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Splendid, splendid!

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: (looking Jekyll up and down) You look much brighter yourself, sir - beggin' your pardon. WE HOLD as Jekyll stops and turns to the Park Keeper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (indicating with stick) Mr. Weller - across the park, in Sir Charles Emery's house - is a beautifully set dinner table. In exactly two hours -somewhere between the beautiful smoked salmon and the beautiful Camembert cheese - Sir Charles will arise and beautifully announce the coming marriage of myself to the most beautiful girl in this beautiful world!

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: (grabbing his hand, pumping it) Dr. Jekyll - my congratulations! And all the best to Mrs. Jekyll as is to be.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: From you, Mr. Weller- that's an omen for happiness. (hand on Mr. Weller's shoulder, in a whisper) You don't blame me if I hurry?

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: (calling after him) God speed, Dr. Jekyll!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Woller! He exits o.s., as Mr. Weller beams after him.

dialogues.speaker: PARK
dialogues.text: He walks through a lovely setting, happily swinging his c

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He walks along, smiling to himself. He starts to whistle. is whistling "Champagne Charlie"! He whistles it with gre volume and vehemence. He suddenly realizes what he is whistling and stops it, a shadow crossing his face. Then smiles again, starts whistling "Drink To Me Only With Thi Eyes", but before he realizes it, he is whistling "Champa Charlie" again. He stops short in his tracks, as he reali this. His hand passes over his brow. He tries to walk on, straightening his shoulders. He seems to feel faint. He l about, a little confused, and WE PAN HIM as he goes to a round bench under a tree and sits down. 218 219 220  221 222 115.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He seems to be trying to get his breath. He rings his fin around the edge of his collar. Then he contorts a little. His face suddenly becomes strained and panic-stricken. Hi hand goes to his throat. His face starts to contort more, the lines deepening. With horror, his glance goes to his hands. WE PAN DOWN. His hand, clutching the bench, is tur more horribly grotesque than we have ever seen it. WE PAN BACK UP. Jekyll is now nearing the change to Hyde! He loo at his other hand. WE PAN DOWN. It is the same as the oth WE PAN BACK UP to his face. It is almost that of Hyde. He in convulsions.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (with a last desperate cry) Bee - Bee, darling -! Then the writhings and gaspings, their course running qui than before. And suddenly, he is Hyde! He looks about, craftily, viciously. A bird lights on the bench beside hi He flails his cane at it. It flies away. He thinks a seco getting his bearings in Evil. Then a thought strikes him. His eyes glint. He starts to sing "Champagne Charlie" ina horrible sing-song, swaying manner, and suddenly he gets with an animal leap, and WE PAN HIM as he runs leaping ac the green into the b.g., like a gorged buzzard racing for another piece of carrion, as we --

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: She is quite tight, tipsily pouring champagne into a glas humming indistinctly to herself. Then she gets an idea an WE PAN HER to mirror. She raises the glass.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (with hatred) Here's hoping that Hyde rots wherever he is - and burns slow when the time comes! (then softly, passionately) And here's hoping that Dr. Jekyll thinks of his Ivy - like I know he'd like to... like Ivy thinks of him... "cause he's an angel. Here's to my angel... Her glass starts for her lips, when suddenly the door ope reflected in the b.g. Hyde stands there, staring at her. turns with a gasp of horror and disbelief, drops the glas to the floor.  223 116.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 223
dialogues.text: He comes slowly down the stairs, throwing his hat and sti on a table, eyeing the frozen Ivy all the while. He start across to her.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (shocked to soberness) Why, sir - I -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: It couldn't be that you didn't expect to see me, could it?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Why, no, sir - I - I've been here waitin' for you, sir. I -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: But you're celebrating. What? Some new event - some change?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: No, sir - I just thought I'd -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (fury starting to win over sarcasm) Drinking to calm your nerves, perhaps? It's your nerves, isn't it? Shouldn't you see a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, sir. (going to wine cooler) Would you like some wine, sir? I'll get another glass and -- Hyde slaps the bottle from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Jekyll's a good man. Dr. Henry Jekyll --

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (now very startled) Is - is he, sir? But I don't need any --

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: A gentleman, too - different than any man you might know. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mimicking) "A nice fine gentleman like yourself wouldn't be meeting such a person -" (as Ivy only stares at him) ",,. I ain't a bad looker when I'm more myself..." (as she starts to back away, he follows her) He's the sort of man you get down on your knees to, isn't he? -- A sweet, dear, pure man you could believe and trust... (suddenly grabs her wrist viciously) He's a smug hypocritical coward, that's what he is!

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: You - you couldn't know Dr. Jekyll -- know him intimately. I detest him intimately -- from his lofty brain to the soles of his virtuous feet. And you -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (mimicking) "I'll do anything you ask, sir -" (snarling again) Well, you saw the respectable fool! Clutched his halo and held it straight, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: How - how'd you know all that?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Why I know everything you say and everything you think.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: Then you - you must be truly somethin' - the devil himself, then... because Dr. Jekyll wouldn't tell you. He ain't the kind that would -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: S-s-h! Would you keep a secret if I told you? Promise?

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: What -? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: I am Dr. Jekyll. I'm the angel you want to love and adore.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (breaks away, back to wall) No - no -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (wagging his finger at her - following) But you don't have to promise. Because it's such a beautiful secret that those who share it with me can't go on living.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: What - what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (softly) How does one usually stop a person from living? He makes a lunge at her, but she ducks from under him, wrenches away from his grasp and, screaming, runs across room, up the stair. Hyde gives a roar of glee and rage, l over balustrade and intercepts her, as WE PAN. WE PAN BAC as she runs screaming across the room, trying to get toa window. Hyde leaps back and grabs her as she reaches diva

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING OVER DIVAN 224
dialogues.text: Hyde grabs her by the throat, bends her back.

dialogues.speaker: IVY
dialogues.text: (wild in her terror) No - please, sir - I'll sing for you, I will - (starts singing) "Champagne Ivy is my name. Champagne Ivy is --" Her voice chokes off.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (yelling) Now! Now you've got what you've longed for! (they start sinking out of sight behind divan) Here - with your angel! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Embraced in the wings of your angel! (as we hear Ivy choke and gasp o.s.) Leda - loved by her swan..! After a second there is silence. Hyde gets up gasping. He looks about, looks back at form below FRAME, and then WE as he picks up his hat and stick and starts for the door. O.s. in the hall, we hear inaudible but growing murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: UPPER HALL AND STAIR WELL 225
dialogues.text: An elderly woman and her husband, and a couple of other tenants are looking fearfully at Ivy's door. Marcia and Freddie, both in evening dress, are hurrying up the stair

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (down to them) Somethin's happened! He's latherin' the hide off her!

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: (to man above) Come on - we better pop in and stop it! At this moment, Hyde comes out the door on the run, stops he sees them.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, you - what've you been -? He gets no further as Hyde brushes him aside with a roar, careens down the stairs to Freddie and Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Stop him, the dirty -! Freddie tries to grapple with Hyde, but Hyde knocks him d with a blow from his cane, and as WE PAN, leaps over the balustrade with a laugh in time to avoid other tenants wh come rushing up the stairs. In the b.g., below, he ducks of the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET 226
dialogues.text: Hyde comes out of the door, darts off down the street. A couple of passers-by turn around and look at him as he le the sidewalk, ducks across in front of a cab, hitting the horse with his cane so that it rears and plunges, and the disappears around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: INT. IVY'S PARLOR 227
dialogues.text: We are shooting over back of divan. Marcia, Freddie, and other tenants are looking horrified down at a constable w is kneeling over Ivy's body o.s. Marcia, hard Marcia, is sobbing. Freddie has his handkerchief to a bloody temple.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (in awe) He done her in! How horrible!

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: (rising) This here's the work of a friend!

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (bursting out) It was that Hyde did it, I tell you! The constable turns, jumps to the window, opens it, start blowing his whistle vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACK JEKYLL'S LAB. 228
dialogues.text: Hyde hurries into scene, looks about with triumphant litt chuckles, as he fumbles in his pockets for the key. WE DO IN. Then Hyde realizes he has destroyed the key. He tries the heavy door with his shoulder, tries again. He gives u looks around, then WE PAN HIM as he darts along sidewalk corner, turns, and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT CORNER 229
dialogues.text: Hyde comes running from back corner full tilt, and WE PAN HIM, after he peers around front corner of his house, alo front of house to entrance and the door, in far b.g.

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: He pulls out the wire plunger bell, frantically, then ban the heavy brass knocker on the door. He flies into a flur of animal rage in his impatience. Then the door opens abo a foot, held in that position by the heavy safety chain stretching from jamb to door on the inside, and Poole's startled face peers out. He withdraws a little at the man sees.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Come - open up, you fool! I'ma friend of Dr. Jekyll! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: D-D-Doctor Jekyll isn't at home, sir... Poole tries to close door but Hyde pushes his foot in, we it open.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Well, that doesn't make any -! (then recovering) What difference does that make? He expects me! He told me to wait for him, you idiot! Let me in!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (firmly) I know all of Dr. Jekyll's friends -!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Now look here - I'll have no insolent talk like -

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: You'll have to come back later.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: You open up or I'll bash this door in!

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: If you don't go away, I'll send for the police! As he says this, he stamps on Hyde's foot. Hyde withdraws it, allowing Poole to slam the door closed. Then with an inarticulate growl, Hyde looks about him for something. W PAN DOWN AND UP with him, as with superhuman strength, he wrenches a foot scraper embedded in the brick stoop. He i just about to use it to jimmy open the door between the h and the jamb, when he does a "double take" and looks o.s.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBIE
dialogues.text: Far down at the corner, he is just emerging into view, strolling along the street at right angles to Hyde. He st and leans against a light post, folding his arms for a re

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HYDE 232
dialogues.text: He realizes his plan is futile. He softly lowers the foot scraper, tiptoes o.s.  233 234 235 236 237 238 239 122.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 233
dialogues.text: He scurries out from entrance to his house, and down the street away from the bobbie.

dialogues.speaker: CHEAP COMMERCIAL SECTION
dialogues.text: The street is empty. In the far background, across the st we see the skulking figure of Hyde, looking in the variou shops as he hurries along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to be searching for a certain shop, passing a butcher's, a shoemaker's, a wine shop, a plumbing shop, n store, etc., peering into each with a sort of desperation Finally, o.s. ahead of him, he sees what he wants. His fa lights up. He is just about to start for it, when he look down the street o.s., from where we hear the sound of tro hooves. He ducks into a dark recess, watches.

dialogues.speaker: HIS ANGLE
dialogues.text: They trot down the street, looking this way and that.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HYDE 237
dialogues.text: He watches them o.s., as the sound of their horses' hoove disappears. Then WE DOLLY AND PAN HIM as he hurries a few paces down the black street until he comes opposite a sto window which reads: "Grundy & Co. Stationery Supplies". H peers in the window.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: They are on display.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HYDE 239
dialogues.text: He tries the door of the shop; of course, it isn't open. looks about, sees a newspaper rack - a heavy wooden stand seizes it, raises it above his head and smashes the windo with it. He reaches in and snags paper, ink bottle, pen. Envelopes and paper scatter over the walk. Almost immedia a light goes on in back of the store as a door opens and man and his wife and an older woman rush into the front p of store. Hyde is now scooting up the sidewalk toward the b.g. The store folk come out, in nightclothes, viewing th wreckage, spying Hyde darting up the street.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: (screaming) There he goes -! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (still sleepy, running about in circles) This ain't no place to rob...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER WOMAN
dialogues.text: (yelling) But robbed it is -! (calling up street) Help - police! (viewing shattered glass) Ooo, the window - and just been cleaned, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the guests are just taking their leave, men b helped on with their capes by a couple of footmen. Atmosp is strained. Ad lib: (sotto voce) "A bit odd, isn't it... I've heard strange things about this young Jekyll... afte all, that affair at the embassy... felt so sorry for poor Beatrix." WE PAN ACROSS this to pick up Sir Charles and Beatrix in the far b.g., bidding goodnight to a weezy old bloke. Lanyon is staying behind, hovering in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (the wheezy old bloke) Goodnight, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (keeping up appearances) Goodnight, Geoffrey...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (to Beatrix) Sorry your young man was detained, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (very strained) So am I, Uncle Geoffrey. It must have been a matter of life or death -

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable, sensing strain) Of course. These doctors... never can call their soul their own... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes o.s. Lanyon, Sir Charles and Beatrix are all uncomfortable, as they watch him go. Hobson, the butler, appears coming from the b.g., wearing top coat and carryi his bowler.

dialogues.speaker: HOBSON
dialogues.text: (conscious of last people leaving in foyer, in a low voice) I talked to Poole. Dr. Jekyll left the house at seven to come here. He's very worried, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (to Sir Charles) There - you see, Father? There must be something more than what you -

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (looking at Beatrix, directly) That is all, Hobson. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOBSON
dialogues.text: (exiting o.s.) Yes, sir. WE DOLLY INTO GROUP as Hobson leaves. Sir Charles looks a

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (bursting out) Father, darling - don't look that way -!

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (gently) My dear - I forbid you to see that man again...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (anguished) I'll disobey you, Father... why I won't even have to disobey you! Harry will come to me. Don't make a scene out of this. You know there must be a reason why he wasn't here -!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Sir Charles - if you'll excuse me - it's late and I rather think I'd better - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: John - don't - we've nothing to hide from you - from anybody. You're Harry's friend - and mine -!

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (almost shouting) Beatrix -!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (her chin up) Yes -?

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: Please go to your room!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Father, I -!

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (sternly) You spoke yesterday of safeguarding your happiness. You must admit you've failed in that tonight. Now it's up to me. Go to your room!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (after a tense pause) Very well, Father. But, tomorrow, Harry will have an explanation. I know that. And then I might be forced to hurt you - very deeply.... With this, she turns, as WE PAN HER toward the stairs, an

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL
dialogues.text: Lanyon is just letting himself in with his key. Briggs, h man, hurries in from the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh, yes sir - (as he takes Lanyon's hat, he picks up an envelope from the console) There was a ring at the door a short while ago, sir. I answered but there was nobody there. I found this envelope had been pushed under.... Lanyon takes it quickly, opens it. Two keys are inside, w a note.  126.

dialogues.speaker: LETTER
dialogues.text: I am in frightful trouble. I beg you to do what I ask. Enclosed is the key to my laboratory, and one to the cabi marked D. Go there at once and get the vials marked AMS and Z and bring them to your house. Remain there alone. A midnight a man will call for the package. Give it to him. the name of Heaven - don't fail me. Harry.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (after a second's thought - taking hat from Briggs) I'm going out again.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGGS
dialogues.text: (following him to the door) Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (at door) And, oh yes - I won't need you any more tonight, Briggs. You may retire.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGGS
dialogues.text: (as Lanyon goes out) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CABINET D
dialogues.text: WE PULL BACK just as Lanyon's hand is inserting the key. Poole is standing by him, puzsled by his mysterious attit

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Is Dr. Jekyll at the hospital? I could fetch him whatever he wishes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: No... (he selects from an array of vials those marked A, M, S, Z - looks at them puzzled - them to Poole) You don't happen to know, I suppose - what Dr. Jekyll uses any of these vials for? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (loyally) I'm sure it's for some of his recent experiments, sir. Lanyon finds an empty vial case, starts putting in vials, we

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANYON'S HOUSE 246
dialogues.text: He is just about to turn into the walk leading up to the front door when Hyde jumps out from behind the shadow of bush. Lanyon steps back, startled. He holds vial case und his cloak.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Well, well - have you got it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (gripping his stick) I beg your pardon. What were you doing hiding behind that -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (in feeble grin of explanation) Just - just waiting for you, Dr. Lanyon. I'm the man from Dr. Jekyll - the package - (then more like a dope fiend) Where is it? I'll take it now.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Step into the house for a moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: No, no - there isn't time - there -!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (rather severely) As Jekyll's friend, I have the right to ask you a few questions. Come, sir! He starts on up the walk. Hyde looks after him wildly, as though he would like to kill him. Then he follows him. As they reach the door, we

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANYON'S STUDY
dialogues.text: Lanyon has just removed his cape and hat in the hall. Hyd eyes the vial case anxiously, as they walk into the study and Lanyon goes behind his desk. He turns the lamp on the desk higher. Hyde keeps his cape on, hat in hand.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (as they walk, gruff) Now come, Lanyon - let's not waste time with a lot of prying questions. Give me the -

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (turning quickly) I resent your attitude, sir. You haven't even introduced yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (impatiently, twitching) Hyde's the name. Mr. Hyde. But what difference does -?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Are you an acquaintance of Jekyll?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Of course. I'ma friend - an old friend. (reaching out his hand, his voice rising) But if you even pretend to be his friend you'll forego your asinine amenities and let me have that before -

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Where is Dr. Jekyll?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (getting more and more impatient) Oh, don't worry - he's alive - he -

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Is he ill? Is -

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He'll be perfectly all right, I tell you!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (opening drawer in desk) Very well, then. I'll go with you and see for myself.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he reaches in drawer, he takes his eyes off Hyde for a second. The latter leaps across and grabs the vial case f Lanyon's hand.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (as he does so; with a snarl) You pretentious fool -! But his expression changes as Lanyon whips a revolver out the drawer and covers him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (evenly) I warn you, Hyde. If you make one step toward the door I'll shoot you right between the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (getting a trapped feeling) Now wait a moment, Lanyon - I can't let you come with me - and I can't tell you any more than I've already -

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Because - well - (then shouting) I warn you not to stick your nose into this! You better let me go, Lanyon! You can ask Jekyll all about it tomorrow if you want to!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: You'll take me to Harry Jekyll this minute!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (screaming his impotence) For the last time, Lanyon - let me out of here - alone!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: For the last time - no!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: (wildly) All right then! Let it be on your own head! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With a wild laugh, he takes out the vials and starts mixi them. Lanyon watches this, puzzled, thinking him complete mad. When the potion is all mixed, Hyde picks up the glas and faces Lanyon. The potion boils and steams a little.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Once more - will you let me take this glass and leave?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (tense, still with revolver ) No. This will be seen through to the end.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: You'd better think again, Lanyon. Do you want to live on as you have... lulled in your blissful cocoon of ignorance? Or do you want that safe peace of mind - your reason even - blasted by a sight that would shock the lowest fiend in the Inferno?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (getting an awful feeling, but game) You can't persuade me with all that mad babbling! Whatever you're going to do - get on with it!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: Very well, Lanyon. But remember your vows to your profession. You'll see a secret you are sworn not to reveal...you who have sneered at the powers of science - you who have laughed at man's ability to dissect his own soul! Watch this, you pompous ass! Watch this!

dialogues.speaker: HE HOLDS THE GLASS HIGH... 248
dialogues.text: ...then drains it. Immediately he goes into his gasping contortions, falls back into a chair. As the metamorphosi from Hyde to Jekyll takes place, Lanyon watches it in hor With a final gasp, Jekyll finally leans back in his chair exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: As Lanyon stands watching, transfixed, the gun falling to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: LANYON
dialogues.text: 251 252 As he sinks into chair, opposite Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Horrible...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He looks at Lanyon o.s., in mute appeal for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (finally) I warned you, John - even as Hyde, I warned you...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: You - you mean those experiments - they -?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yes, John... 131. 250 251 252 Lanyon gets up and starts pacing nervously, as Jekyll wat him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: It's sheer horror... I can't believe it... (stops in front of Jekyll) You see what you've done, don't you. You've gone beyond - you've tampered with - you've committed the supreme blasphemy!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (in great anguish from here on) I know - I know...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: You must destroy the formula, do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I've done that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: But you must destroy it from your mind! You must never take it again! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stops, 132. 252

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: know - but this evening - on my way to - on my way to Sir Charles'... you see, I always thought I could control it, John - but this evening - the change - the change to this - this monster Hyde - happened without anything - without - unable to go on, covers his face with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (in awe) I) T's diabolical...

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: And it might happen again - (lifts his face to Lanyon, and pounds chair arm with his fist) But I'll fight it! I'm going to fight it -! (then stops with a sudden remembrance, his face growing blank with a new horror) Oh -! He rises suddenly, walks across the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (watching him) What -?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I'm a murderer, John. A murderer! (looking about wildly) I who wanted to serve the living!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: You mean you actually -?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Yes! Tonight! There was a girl - a poor beaten girl that I - that he knew... and I went to her - and choked her to death - (incredulously looking at his hands) - choked out her life with these - no, not with these hands - not with these hands -! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sinks down into a chair again, covering his face, tryi to keep from hysteria. Lanyon walks to the fireplace, loo into the flames.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: Harry - Man cannot flaunt the Divinity of Man without being eternally damned... (turns to Jekyll, with quiet abruptness) - what about Beatrix? Have you thought of her?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (he looks up slowly, in a dull voice) I'll have to give her up, of course... (then, his hysteria mounting) I've known it all along - I'll have to face it now - now when I need her most - but I'll give her up! I promise I will! (now dropping to hoarse pleading) But John, after that I'll need more help than ever. You can help me. You must help me! I must win over this thing! I must - He stops as he realizes that Lanyon is looking at him wit mixture of unrolenting condemnation and pity. He realizes is up against the inovitable. He chokes, buries his face his hands again, as we

dialogues.speaker: UPPER HALL
dialogues.text: Poole comes up the steps, carrying a morning paper and a tray of tea. As he walks, he reads the paper, uttering clucking noises and shaking his head. We PAN HIM to Jekyl bedroom door. He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JEKYLL'S BEDROOM 254
dialogues.text: Jekyll, in his dressing gown, is leaning against the wind looking out as Poole enters. The bed is turned down but n slept in.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE 255
dialogues.text: As he enters, he looks at Jekyll o.s., and then at bed o.  256 257 258 259 260 261 262 134.

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: It is just as he turned it down last night.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO POOLE 257
dialogues.text: He looks from the bed to Jekyll o.s.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL 258
dialogues.text: He feels Poole's hesitancy.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (worn and haggard looking) Just put the tray down, Poole.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: He walks over to the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (puts paper down with tray) I don't know what things are coming to, sir. If you'll forgive me - there was the most ghastly murder in Diadem Court last evening. A poor girl was -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (suddenly shouting) P) Oole! Will you get out?

dialogues.speaker: POOL
dialogues.text: (shocked and puzzled) Oh, yes sir. Very good, sir. Poole retires, yet stopping to look back at Jekyll with a worried look. When Poole has gone, Jekyll's eye goes to t paper. He can't help himself. He goes over and picks it u

dialogues.speaker: HEADLINE AND STORY
dialogues.text: GIRL MURDERED BY MONSTER Witnesses Tell of Beast Last eve a man known only as "Hyde" and "an evil monster" by tenan at --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JEKYLL 262
dialogues.text: He throws the paper from him. He sits down on the bed, gr the post, and raises his gaze upwards. He is in lonely anguish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: _ (praying) â€” This I did not intend. I thought I was serving You. I saw a light - but I did not realize it led only to Darkness. Forgive me. Help me to - He cannot go on, knowing he has lost the right even to as for help. His eyes close, and he leans his head against t post, as we

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He comes hesitantly along the walk, stick in hand, the li from the house illuminating his drawn and agonized expres His pace slackens as he turns in through the grilled iron gate as WE PAN and he walks toward the front door in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He can hardly bring himself to pull the bell plunger. Sud he is aware of the dim sound of a piano o.s. He realizes that Beatrix is playing. WE PAN HIM as he walks down the front of the house to the end of the "side" garden.

dialogues.speaker: FORMAL SIDE GARDEN 265
dialogues.text: Jekyll comes around the corner of the house and walks acr a small flagged veranda which leads from French windows o the drawing room to the flower garden. The garden centers about a small fountain and is set off with flower-bed pat and marble benches.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: He peers through them in the b.g. We see Beatrix playing piano, a sad and worried expression on her face. Back of her, and to one side, Sir Charles nods in a chair over a paper.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: We are on his tortured countenance for a second as he loo o.s. at Beatrix. He half raises his hand as though to cal her attention by the movement.  136.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS
dialogues.text: She suddenly sees him. She falters in her playing for a second. Jekyll puts his finger to his lips. She continues playing and finishes her piece very softly, watching Sir Charles over her shoulder, who by now is quite asleep. Th she gets up and hurries as quickly as possible without ma any noise to the French doors, opens them, and comes out Jekyll, closing the doors quietly.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (seeing his strained look) Harry - dearest -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (nodding toward garden) Will you come out - where we can talk? She gives him a worried look, and then precedes him out i the garden.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX AND JEKYLL 269
dialogues.text: As they come into SCENE, near a marble bench. He is great agitated. He doesn't know where to begin. Beatrix sits do on the bench. She indicates the place beside her.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Sit down, darling - what's happened? What's wrong? Jekyll sits down, staring at the ground, wringing his han For a moment, there is silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (bursting out suddenly) Bee -- I - I've been thinking -- about us. I think your father's been right all along....

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I - I don't think we should ever marry, that's all. I - I realized it, last night. And - and I think you ought to break it off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (slowly, unable to believe) What are you trying to tell me, Harry? You don't know what you're saying... look at me -!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (his face averted) Really, Bee --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (pulling his shoulders around) Look at me, darling -!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I mean - no matter how perfect things seem at first - people make mistakes, sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (tears welling in her eyes) But, Harry... (then, with the horrible thought) Oh... I see. You don't want me. You don't love me any more. Is that it? (stifling a sob) Are you telling me you don't want me?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (wildly, breaking) Want you? I love you and want you more than -- (rises quickly, walks away ) But I'm giving you up, do you hear? I'm not worth even the sound of your name! Beatrix gets up and hurries to him as WE PAN.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Oh, my darling - what's wrong? Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I've no right to you - I've thrown it away!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: Nothing's done that can't be -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: But it's done! I've destroyed paradise - Our paradise -

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (the mother now) Oh - you are ill - tell me what's really wrong! Don't keep it pent up inside. You've always said we could discuss anything between us.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: There are things you can't voice in Heaven. Just believe me... (turning his back to her) You're giving me up, do you hear? Go - go inside - now - while I can't see you -!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (turning him half to her) Darling - it's all right. Just take me in your arms.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: Oh, don't my angel! Angel - Angel of Heaven, don't say any more -!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (putting her arms around him) There - there, darling - hold me close. Don't think of anything - of whatever it is - just hold me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (pulling her hand from him) No! No - I can't! I'd give my soul to -- but I have no soul! (he clenches his fist and covers his face with the other hand, bowing his head) I'm like - (he pauses, searching for the word) - like the living dead...! Beatrix now enfolds him in her arms again. His head rests her shoulder. His arms go around her, weakened for a mome in his anguish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (soothingly) Oh, my poor dear suffering love. Be quiet... s-s-h-don't say any more.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Oh, Bee - my darling -!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (softly) Rest now... rest... They are quiet for a second. Then Jekyll lifts his head quickly and starts as if to leave.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (trying to hold him, panicky) I won't let you go. You love me - I won't let you go.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (his voice rising) That's why I'm giving you up! Because I'll love you till the end of time! (raising his gaze aloft, as he backs away, Beatrix staring after him aghast that he is going, that she can't hold him) This is my proof! This is my penance! He turns and walks hurriedly o.s.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (starting after him, then stops) Harry - come back - Harry -- She then breaks into violent sobs, falters, and sinks to ground, prone.  270 271 140.

dialogues.speaker: END OF GARDEN 270
dialogues.text: Jekyll is hurrying toward the CAMERA. In the b.g., Beatri is sobbing on the ground. WE PAN Jekyll as he comes aroun the side of the house and stops. 0.s. he hears her sobbin faintly. He is terribly tempted to go back. He half turns and looks. He cannot stand the sight of what he sees. He leans in weary torture against the side of the house, clo his eyes. Suddenly a look of horror comes over his face. looks down at his hands. WE PAN DOWN to see his hand star to change. WE PAN UP to Jekyll's face. He looks down at h other hand. His throat starts to constrict, his face to change.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (wildly, looking up) Oh - no - no - don't let me - save me - don't let me -! But the metamorphosis is well on its way.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX 271
dialogues.text: She still lies on the ground, sobbing. Then, Jekyll's fee and legs appear slowly in the SCENE. They stand right nex to her. She is aware of them. With a little sob, she half rises, reaches out and enfolds the legs, pressing her che against the knees.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Oh, you did come back... Oh, my darling.... For answer there is an ugly chuckle o.s. Hyde's hands com down into the frame and clutch her arms. Beatrix in puzzlement, and then in dawning horror reacts to the chuc and the hands. In almost the same moment, Hyde lifts her and she is face to face with him. For a second, she is fr with fright, then screams as Hyde's face bends towards he

dialogues.speaker: BEATRIX
dialogues.text: (after her scream) Father! Father..! Hyde laughs wildly and starts to struggle with Beatrix.  272 273 274 275 141.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES 272
dialogues.text: He is coming out of the drawing room on a dead run. WE PA HIM over to Beatrix and Hyde. Hyde drops Beatrix who fain and slips to the ground. Sir Charles makes a gallant lung at Hyde, but Hyde sends him reeling against the wall. The with a wild animal laugh he leaps for his hat and stick. Charles, however, recovers in time to intercept his progr around the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: SIR CHARLES
dialogues.text: (calling) Help! Hobson - call the police! Help -! Hyde raises his stick and lays it across Sir Charles' hea Sir Charles stumbles back and falls to the ground. Hyde l on top of him like a panther, and bashes the stick agains Sir Charles' head three or four times in rapid succession The stick breaks with a final sickening blow. In the b.g. Hobson and a footman come hurrying from the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Here - what's going on -! They spy Hyde and come after him. Hyde gets up and WE PAN HIM the length of the garden on the run. Hobson kneels be Sir Charles' prostrate body as the footman gives chase af Hyde around the corner of the house.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT GATE 273
dialogues.text: Hyde comes running from the garden. He stops for a second and looks up the street.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL'S ANGLE 274
dialogues.text: A constable comes around the corner on the run, dimly discernible under a gas light.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HYDE 275
dialogues.text: He runs o.s. down the street in the opposite direction ju as the footman appears and the constable comes running up

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: (pointing in direction of Hyde) There he goes! It's the monster! The constable runs o.s. after Hyde, blowing his whistle.  276 277 278 279 280 281 282 283 142.

dialogues.speaker: MEWS 276
dialogues.text: Hyde comes tearing down in toward camera. In a second, th constable appears after him. Another man or two, passers- at the far entrance, take up the chase. Hyde leaps over a fence. When the constable arrives at fence, he blows his whistle again.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: He reacts to distant whistle, runs for it o.s.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He runs past camera into b.g. A small group of idlers are standing at the corner. They block his progress and he bo through them, knocking a couple down. Ad 1ib yells of sur and anger.

dialogues.speaker: STREET 279
dialogues.text: The two constables come in chase, followed by more people

dialogues.speaker: 1ST CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Stop that man!

dialogues.speaker: AT CORNER 280
dialogues.text: As constables come running up.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST MAN
dialogues.text: (pointing) That way, constable! WE PAN AND PICK UP Hyde, his cape flying, leaping down th street in the b.g. The rest give chase.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He comes flying along and darts up the walk to the house. O.s. comes the sound of the constable's whistle.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He runs up the steps, vaults the balustrade and hurls his body sidewise through the waiting-room window at the side the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WAITING-ROOM 283
dialogues.text: Hyde lands sprawling amidst the shattered glass. He scram up and leaps out into the foyer.  284 285 286 287 288 289 290 143.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOYER
dialogues.text: Hyde enters. Poole comes in from past camera.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (recognizing Hyde) Here, here - how did -? But he gets no further as Hyde, with a roar, bowls him as and ducks out the back door toward the lab. Poole hurries the door, opens it. 0.s. we hear crowd noises and whistle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he leaps across the bridge in the back courtyard to Jekyll's laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMALL HALL
dialogues.text: Hyde comes through door from courtyard, closes door, lock it. Then he goes to door of lab, opens it, ducks inside, we hear him lock this door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poole and the constables come running across the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: He's gone into the laboratory! WE PAN THEM to the first door. They find it locked.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: (putting shoulder to door) Heave, Bill!

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: He is frantically looking for various vials to mix the po He upsets and breaks things in his fury.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDEN
dialogues.text: A constable, the footman, Hobson and Lanyon are leaning o Sir Charles' body. Lanyon is shaking his head woefully. T constable shows Lanyon half of a stick.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is the weapon what done it, Doctor.  291 292 293 294 295 296

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (taking stick, then after a second) Yes... I was afraid so. (rising) Come - I think I can take you to your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyde is feverishly mixing the potion, having to make some its ingredients not already prepared. O.s., there is a cr of door bursting. Then hammering on the laboratory door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL OF LAB 293
dialogues.text: The courtyard door is down. The constables and Poole are hammering at the door of the lab.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE
dialogues.text: In his haste, he knocks over a large glass jar. It crashe

dialogues.speaker: 1ST CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: (suddenly listening) He's in there! Open up! (then, as just silence comes) Come on, Bill! Bill has run in with a crow-bar, and after two or three t they break the door down.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE AND CONSTABLES
dialogues.text: They come running down the stairs. As WE PAN WE PICK UP J who is just staggering to his feet from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (amazed) Dr. Jekyll, sir! That frightful maniac broke through the house and -

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I know. He struck me over the head. (indicating, to constable) Quick, man! He went out by the back! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The constables hurry to the back door, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: I didn't even know you were home, sir. Are you badly hurt?

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: I'll - I'll be all right. The two constables come from the back door.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: (to Jekyll) This here door's locked.

dialogues.speaker: JEKYLL
dialogues.text: (impatiently, pointing up stairs) Then you better get round through the front! The two constables leap up the stairs, just as Lanyon, an constable and an inspector in plain clothes come hurrying in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (looking at Jekyll below) Wait!

dialogues.speaker: 1ST CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: (explaining) He ducked through the back and locked the door after him!

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (in great strain) No, he didn't! He's still down here. They watch him, amazed, and follow down the steps to the proper. He approaches Jekyll. Jekyll looks at him, tired, wan. There are tears in Jekyll's eyes as he waits for the word by Lanyon. Lanyon, too, is greatly affected. He seem as though he can't say the word.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (finally gathers himself - pointing to Jekyll) There - Heaven help him.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (shocked) Dr. Lanyon -! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (Puzzled) I know this gentleman. He's Dr. Jekyll.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (tears in his eyes now) I know. Nevertheless, there's your man.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You can't be serious, Dr. Lanyon. I -

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (suddenly pointing) Watch -! For Jekyll has already started to turn back to Hyde again They all watch him in awe and horror as he goes through t metamorphosis.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE 297
dialogues.text: He backs away slowly.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLES AND INSPECTOR 298
dialogues.text: Their jaws are dropping.

dialogues.speaker: LANYON 299
dialogues.text: He looks away. He cannot stand it.

dialogues.speaker: HYDE 300
dialogues.text: For he is now almost completely Hyde. He comes out of his writhings as such. He looks about at the others, as thoug he has just seen them for the first time. He is more best and awful in physique and manner than we have ever seen h in the transformation. With a sudden yell he throws a hug jar at the officers, and ducks around the table. (NOTE: I the following ensuing struggle ad lib commands from the inspector should come at the proper time: "Grab him - hol him - don't let him get up those stairs - guard that door etc.) Hyde practically wrecks the lab in eluding his purs He knocks them this way and that. He leaps across tables up on shelves, pulling them down. He growls and snarls an laughs in glee every time he eludes them.

dialogues.speaker: LANYON AND INSPECTOR 301
dialogues.text: This during middle of fight. Lanyon sees the gun in the inspector's hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (pleading) Shoot him, inspector - shoot him! That would be his wish!

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (grimly ) Must take him if we can! (darting o.s.) Hold him now!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP 302
dialogues.text: The constables seem just about to have Hyde cornered, whe with another wild leap, he gets to a set of surgical instruments, and pulls out a large knife. With another ye he makes a leap for freedom, brandishing his weapon. As h gets by the large apparatus on the table, the inspector l him have it with the revolver. Hyde wheels, drops across table, shattering some of the apparatus. They start crowd around him in silent awe, Poole crying with audible sobs.

dialogues.speaker: POOLE
dialogues.text: (like a plea) Dr. Jekyll... Dr. Jekyll..... !

dialogues.speaker: HYDE'S HEAD
dialogues.text: There is a strange light on it. As if in answer to Poole' plea, the face starts slowly and mystically changing back that of the handsome Jekyll - a face peaceful in death - if in death - without struggle or torture - Jekyll was restored to himself for Eternity. WE PULL BACK SLOWLY for tableau.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LANYON
dialogues.text: (line to come)
